6. Conclusions
Methanol is a large-scale bulk chemical that is currently manufactured from common fossil hydrocarbon feedstocks. Methanol synthesis
is one of the possible solutions to the energy challenges that we face in the 21st century as it may be produced from renewable resources
and has an energy density that allows demanding long-distance transport without refueling. Methanol is also an excellent precursor for
making many bulk chemicals including oleﬁns, formaldehyde, acetic acid, methyl chloride, DME, dimethyl terephthalate, etc.
One of the main challenges in lowering the environmental footprint of the methanol industry, using small rural gas supplies, biomass
gasiﬁcation or CO 2waste streams combined with H 2from electrolysis, is the demand for more economic solutions for smaller production
plants. It will be difﬁcult for smaller plants to compete with new world class-methanol-plants fueled by cheap natural gas on an equal basis
so subsidies and regulations will be needed in a transition period. However, in a low CO 2emission society, where ﬂaring is unacceptable,
small-scale methanol production could be attractive. The main route to methanol in a foreseeable future is still thermal via synthesis gas as
methanol production via direct electrolysis, photo-catalysis, non-catalytic synthesis and direct methane-to-methanol synthesis, all need
major technological breakthroughs to be commercially interesting.
Today ´s technology provides an applicable solution for combining CO 2and H 2to make methanol, although the industrial methanol syn-
thesis catalyst is slightly less efﬁcient and shows somewhat faster thermal sintering in CO 2rich feed gasses. Making the industrial metha-
nol catalyst even more stable could be interesting, but a really attractive improvement could be to enhance the low temperature activity of
the methanol synthesis catalyst since lower temperatures would allow better equilibrium conditions, lower synthesis pressures, and
thereby decrease the demand for expensive compression especially in smaller productions. Efﬁcient handling of impurities is also an issue
especially in the light of some unconventional impurities present in alternative feed gasses and in this connection a sulfur tolerant synthe-
sis could be highly interesting. Both increasing the knowledge and ﬁnding simpliﬁed solutions to these challenges is of industrial
importance.
Development and understanding of methanol synthesis catalysts are still very active research areas. We could hope that we in the
future, based on experimental evidence, obtain a theoretical description with predictive power to strengthen our search for catalysts with
higher low temperature activity or resistance towards impurities.

using Sentinel-3 imagery

Keywords: 
Remote sensing 
Dissolved carbon dioxide 
Sentinel-3 
Eastern China lakes ABSTRACT  
Satellite observation can significantly reduce the uncertainties in CO2 emission estimations compared to insuf-
ficient field data. However, big challenges remain in developing remote sensing-based models for mapping 
concentrations of dissolved carbon dioxide (cCO2) in lakes at regional or global scales. We developed a cCO2 
estimation model using Sentinel-3-derived lake environmental variables and near-synchronous field cCO2 data 
from 16 lakes in the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze and Huai River (ML_YHR) basins in Eastern China 
(N =248). Stepwise quadratic polynomial regressions of several combinations of chlorophyll- a (Chl-a), water 
temperature (Tw), Secchi disk depth (ZSD), and photosynthetic active radiation (PAR)-related variables were 
tested and validated to select the best approach. The final model showed high performance in calibration and 
validation (R2 >0.72, RMSE <6.35 μmol L�1, MAPE <30.31%). The model sensitivity analysis, based on Monte 
Carlo simulations, showed the model ’s estimated bias as <25% based on uncertainties of all input variables. 
Spatial and temporal dynamics of dissolved CO2 concentrations in 113 lakes (≥10 km2) in the ML_YHR basins 
were mapped from 2016 to 2021 using the Sentinel-3 data. The result showed that CO2 concentrations were low 
in the summer and autumn but high in the winter and spring with dramatic variations (e.g., mean coefficient of 
variation: 52.59%). The annual mean CO2 concentrations of lakes revealed that about 28% of the lakes acted as 
weak atmospheric CO2 sinks (14.96 ±1.13 μmol L�1) while the rest were sources (19.22 ±2.02 μmol L�1), 
compared with a mean concentration of CO2 atmospheric equilibrium (16.29 μmol L�1). CO2 concentrations 
decreased with increasing eutrophication and decreasing lake size (p <0.05). This study advances current 
knowledge about CO2 emissions from emerging meso-eutrophic lakes and shows how satellite remote sensing can 
expand the spatiotemporal coverage of lake CO2.   
1.Introduction 
Lakes play an essential role in the carbon cycle as they emit green -
house gas equivalent to nearly 20% of global fossil fuel CO2 emissions 
(DelSontro et al., 2018 ) despite their small surface area, which is only 
about 3.7% of the global non-glacial land area (Verpoorter et al., 2014 ). 
However, current bottom-up estimates of CO2 emissions from lakes have 
significant uncertainties due to the lack of in situ data. One of the crucial 
reasons for these uncertainties is the large bias of lake type in the global 
lake datasets used in the global emission estimation. Global warming 
and nutrient enrichment due to agriculture and urbanization has increased eutrophication of lakes since the 20th century (Ho et al., 
2019 ). About 63.1% of global lakes larger than 25 km2 are already 
eutrophic, covering about 30.5% of the water surface area (Wang et al., 
2018 ). Eutrophication can largely affect the aquatic carbon cycle by 
promoting atmospheric carbon sequestration as sediment and dissolved 
organic carbon (Pacheco et al., 2014 ). However, only <1% of the 7939 
lakes and reservoirs in the dataset of Raymond et al. (2013) represent 
eutrophic lakes, and most of them are boreal lakes north of the 40◦N 
latitude, resulting in a lack of representativeness of lake types and 
regional distribution, which hinders accurate estimation of global lake 
CO2 emissions.

2The carbon processes in eutrophic lakes are significantly different 
from lakes of other types. The increased inputs of terrestrial carbon 
entering the lake with nutrients increase the lake’s CO2 (Weyhenmeyer 
et al., 2015 ). On the other hand, the algae emerging with increasing 
nutrients promote primary productivity and reduce the lake CO2 
(Pacheco et al., 2014 ). The unclear counterbalance of these two pro-
cesses results in complex carbon cycle roles that create many problems 
for eutrophic lakes (DelSontro et al., 2018 ; Loken et al., 2019 ; Borges 
et al., 2022 ). Specifically, even in tropical lakes reported to be strong 
emitters of CO2 into the atmosphere (Marotta et al., 2009 ), eutrophi -
cation induces high Chl-a, which leads to undersaturated dissolved CO2 
that acts as CO2 sinks (Borges et al., 2022 ). As an eutrophic lake in 
temperate regions, Lake Mendota shows dramatic seasonal CO2 varia -
tions (6.8–184.3 μmol L�1) and significant spatial heterogeneity in the 
autumn mixing period (Loken et al., 2019 ). Furthermore, eutrophication 
can offset or even reverse carbon emissions from an oligotrophic lake 
(Pacheco et al., 2014 ). The size-productivity weighted upscaling esti-
mates of global lakes by DelSontro et al. (2018) were about 50% lower 
than the estimation based on size weighted upscaling alone, which also 
proved the importance of eutrophic lakes in global lake CO2 emission 
estimates. Unfortunately, due to the limitations of labor and material 
resources, it is impossible for field sampling to cover all the lakes within 
the higher frequency than quarterly or annually (Raymond et al., 2013 ; 
Holgerson and Raymond, 2016 ). New large-scale approaches need to be 
developed to fulfill the need to monitor the high spatiotemporal varia -
tions in lakes ’ CO2. 
Satellite remote sensing has accumulated massive continuous 
observation data owing to its broad coverage and high spatiotemporal 
resolution. Based on massive satellite-to-field matchups and high- 
precision satellite products, remote sensing methods have become 
essential for synoptic estimation of oceanic surface dissolved CO2 (Bai 
et al., 2015 ; Chen et al., 2016 ; Chen et al., 2019a ). In principle, the 
oceanic surface dissolved CO2 concentration is mainly controlled by 
thermodynamic processes, biological activities, and physical mixing 
(Takahashi et al., 2002 ; Biswas et al., 2004 ; Takahashi et al., 2009 ). 
These processes can be simulated by satellite-derivable variables such as 
sea surface temperature (SST), sea surface salinity (SSS), Chl-a, and the 
downwelling diffuse attenuation coefficient (Kd) (Bai et al., 2015 ; Chen 
et al., 2016 ; Lohrenz et al., 2018 ). As the sea gets closer to the land, the 
interaction between oceanic CO2-controlling processes and their related 
factors gets stronger, complicating the CO2 estimation model. In open 
oceans, dissolved CO2 is mainly controlled by the thermodynamic pro-
cess, and can be estimated by sea surface temperatures using simple 
linear regression (Boutin et al., 1999 ). In relatively closed bays or coastal 
areas (e.g., the Gulf of Mexico, the Baltic Sea, and the East China Sea) 
where biological and river-sea interactions are enhanced, nonlinear al-
gorithms (e.g., polynomial regression, semi-analytics, machine learning 
algorithms) are required. Variables related to biological processes (Chl- 
a, Kd), physical mixing (SSS) and thermodynamic processes (SST) are 
also necessary inputs used to jointly describe the dynamics of dissolved 
CO2 (Bai et al., 2015 ; Chen et al., 2016 ; Parard et al., 2016 ; Lohrenz 
et al., 2018 ). However, models developed for specific sea areas have 
limitations in regional extrapolation performance. Massive multi- 
regional representative field data and more complicated algorithms (e. 
g., semi-analytical and machine learning algorithms) are needed to 
develop models with general applicability for more sea areas (Chen 
et al., 2017 ; Chen et al., 2019a ). 
Unlike the way it’s handled in the ocean, dissolved CO2 in lakes is 
controlled by endogenous biological effects, thermodynamics, physical 
mixing, and exogenous terrestrial organic and inorganic carbon input 
from rivers (Tranvik et al., 2009 ). In particular, due to the relatively 
small volume of lakes, the exchange of material and energy between 
lakes and terrestrial ecosystems via rivers and lake shorelines is intense, 
profoundly affecting various endogenous biochemical processes in lakes 
(Cole et al., 2007 ; Tranvik et al., 2009 ). In addition to predicting lake 
thermal processes, the water temperature can also indicate photosynthesis intensity together with Chl-a and Kd (Qi et al., 2020 ). 
Dissolved organic carbon (DOC) and coloured dissolved organic matter 
(CDOM) are potential predictors of dissolved CO2, because they are in-
dicators of organic matter mineralization processes or exogenous inputs 
that lead to a CO2 increase (Sobek et al., 2005 ; Raymond et al., 2013 ; 
Klaus et al., 2019 ). However, most lakes lack accurate satellite products 
of the variables discussed in this section. Few studies are currently 
available on the use of satellite products to estimate lake CO2, which has 
severely limited the expansion of long-term remote sensing data 
(Campbell et al., 2022 ). There are only exploratory studies on Lake 
M¨alaren (Kutser et al., 2015 ), Lake Erie (Ouyang et al., 2017 ), and Lake 
Taihu (Qi et al., 2020 ). Among them, a relatively mature study by Qi 
et al. (2020) represents the best model (Taihu model) developed for the 
most well-known eutrophic shallow lake in China - Lake Taihu. This 
study reconstructs nearly 20 years of dissolved CO2 in Lake Taihu, 
thereby proving the potential of satellite remote sensing for long-term 
monitoring of lake CO2 dynamics. However, due to the heterogeneity 
of biogeochemical processes among different types of lakes, it is unclear 
whether the Taihu model can be applied to other lakes worldwide. 
Considerable differences have been found in the optical properties 
between lakes as well as between seasons for the same lake, leading to 
great challenges in developing a uniform algorithm for regional or 
global lakes (Shen et al., 2020 ; Pahlevan et al., 2022 ). For instance, lakes 
in the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze and Huai River 
(ML_YHR) basins include several types of lakes, from mesotrophic to 
highly eutrophic (Hu et al., 2022 ). The highly eutrophic lakes with 
frequent cyanobacterial blooms in the ML_YHR basins include Lake 
Taihu in the Yangtze Delta and Lake Chaohu in Hefei (the capital of the 
Anhui Province) (Duan et al., 2015 ; Duan et al., 2017 ). Besides, there are 
also lakes with a lower eutrophication and a high river –lake connectivity 
with large amounts of suspended matter, such as Lake Hongze, Poyang, 
and Dongting (Hou et al., 2017 ; Shen et al., 2020 ). MODIS data has 
about two decades of earth observations; however, many algorithms 
based on MODIS data were developed for monitoring the long-term 
dynamics of a single lake (e.g., Lake Taihu) (Shi et al., 2015a ; Shi 
et al., 2015b ; Huang et al., 2017 ). Mature MODIS-based water quality 
parameters algorithms for inland waters have not been fully developed 
to date (e.g., Chl-a), because MODIS was developed for open ocean 
waters and does not have spectral bands in the red and NIR part of the 
spectrum which is critical for estimating Chl-a in eutrophic waters 
(Gitelson, 1992 ; Cao et al., 2022b ). The Sentinel-3 Ocean and Land 
Colour Instrument (OLCI) performance in retrieving water quality pa-
rameters in lakes has been well demonstrated by different authors (Xue 
et al., 2019 ; Shen et al., 2020 ; Soomets et al., 2020a ; Soomets et al., 
2020b ; Pahlevan et al., 2022 ), since it was developed specifically for 
coastal and inland waters. MODIS is also close to the end of its life, while 
funding for the next Sentinel-3 (C, D and onward) is secured for decades 
to come. Therefore, we chose to use the OLCI sensor for evaluating the 
lake CO2 even though it has shorter time series at present. Existing 
studies have achieved a high-precision inversion of the primary optical 
parameters (e.g., Chl-a and ZSD) for lakes in the ML_YHR basins based on 
the Sentinel-3 OLCI data (Xu et al., 2019 ; Shen et al., 2020 ). Standard 
surface temperatures and photosynthetic active radiation products 
derived from Sentinel-3 data have been released, which meet the basic 
requirements of the Taihu CO2 model proposed by Qi et al. (2020) . 
Moreover, the reconstruction of dissolved cCO2 in eutrophic lakes will 
help fill the gap in the current global lake dataset, which is of great 
significance for reducing uncertainty concerning the global lake CO2 
emission estimation. 
This study was conducted to achieve three objectives: (1) to 
construct a high-precision dissolved CO2 concentration estimation 
model suitable for lakes in the ML_YHR basins based on Sentinel-3 data; 
(2) to evaluate the performance and uncertainty of the model by veri-
fying the results with our independent data and comparing with the 
existing research in the ML_YHR basins; (3) to reconstruct a multi-year 
series of dissolved CO2 concentrations for lakes in the ML_YHR basins T. Qi et al. 3based on all available multi-year Sentinel-3 satellite data from May 2016 
to December 2021. To the best of our knowledge, this study is the first to 
estimate dissolved CO2 in lakes from space at a regional scale. 
2.Data and methods 
2.1. Study areas 
The middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze and Huai River 
(ML_YHR) basins are located in the eastern plain of China (27.78◦- 
36.10◦N, 111.70◦-121.67◦E, Fig. 1). The ML_YHR basins are in a sub-
tropical monsoon climate region with favorable hydrothermal condi -
tions and abundant water sources to replenish the lakes within it. The 
ML_YHR basins includes 605 natural lakes (excluding reservoirs) larger 
than 1 km2, with a total lake area of 20,762 km2 (Ma et al., 2011 ). Due to 
the fast-growing social and economic development of eastern China in 
the last half century, a large amount of nitrogen-rich sewage was dis-
charged into lakes (Yu et al., 2019 ). This excess nitrogen led to the 
deterioration of aquatic ecosystems and fast eutrophication of ML_YHR 
lakes (Hu et al., 2022 ). The frequent occurrence of cyanobacterial 
blooms endangers the ecological health of lakes and the lives of sur-
rounding residents (Duan et al., 2015 ; Duan et al., 2017 ). At the same 
time, eutrophication dramatically changed the CO2 emission dynamics 
in lakes, making lakes in this region a hotspot for lake-related carbon 
cycle research (Lee et al., 2014 ; Ran et al., 2021 ; Xiao et al., 2022 ). In 
this study, considering the limitations of the spatial resolution 
(approximately 300 m) of the Sentinel-3 OLCI data, 113 lakes (>10 km2) 
located in the ML_YHR basins were examined (Fig. 1). 2.2. Field data 
Based on lake sizes, hydrological conditions, and the trophic status of 
the lakes reported in published studies (Zou et al., 2020 ; Hu et al., 2022 ), 
16 lakes were selected in the ML_YHR basins (as shown in Fig. 1 with 
basic properties shown in Table 1). Six field surveys were conducted in 
July 2018, October 2019, September and October 2020, and April, June, 
and December 2021. For samplings of each lake, 5 to 30 sample points 
were set in the lake’s pelagic area and carried out simultaneously with 
Sentinel-3 overpasses. At each sampling site, surface water samples 
(0–50 cm) were collected to analyses water quality and optical param -
eters (including Chl-a, DOC, CDOM absorbance, and suspended partic -
ulate matter (SPM)). A standard 5 L acrylic water-fetching instrument 
was used to collect the water. The samples were stored in cold dark 
conditions before laboratory analysis. The specific measurement 
methods have been detailed in previous studies (Xue et al., 2017 ; Xiao 
et al., 2020 ). For dissolved cCO2 measurements, a headspace equilib -
rium method based on the workflow of Goldenfum (2010) and Striegl 
et al. (2012) was used. In short, about 16 mL of bubble-free surface 
water samples were injected through a 20 mL polypropylene syringe 
into 30-mL glass serum bottles. The syringe was fitted with a three-way 
stopcock and a 1.2-μm syringe filter. The serum bottles had been pre-
viously flushed with N2 at atmospheric pressure and sealed with stop-
pers at the laboratory. Serum bottles also contained 2 g of potassium 
chloride (KCl) to inhibit microbial activity. CO2 gas volume fractions in 
the headspace gas were measured using a gas chromatograph (Agilent- 
7890B) in the laboratory. cCO2 at field conditions were calculated using 
measured headspace gas volume fractions, averaged total barometric 
pressure at the sample collection site, field water temperatures,

2.3. Satellite data 
Benefitting from the band setting and spatial resolution, the Sentinel- 
3 OLCI is considered one of the most suitable satellite sensors for water 
colour remote sensing in inland waters (IOCCG, 2018 ). Previous study 
has proved the cross-mission consistency of data obtained by OLCI 
sensors equipped on Sentinel-3 A and B (Zibordi et al., 2022 ). Therefore, 
we used the OLCI data that both Sentinel-3 A and B obtained to retrieve 
the lakes ’ optical parameters. Our goal was to obtain the maximum 
number of valid images. The Sentinel-3 A/B OLCI level-1B FR and the 
Sea and Land Surface Temperature Radiometer (SLSTR) level-2 land 
surface temperature (LST) images were downloaded from the European 
Space Agency (ESA) Copernicus Open Access Hub. These images cover 
the ML_YHR basins between May 2016 and December 2021. Image 
quality control and selection were done with the following preprocess -
ing. The Sentinel-3 OLCI level-2 instantaneous PAR (iPAR) product was 
downloaded from the European Organization for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites (EUMETSAT) with online data access at 
https://data.eumetsat.int/ . The MODIS 3 km aerosol product 
(MOD04_3K) was required as an input to the atmospheric correction and 
was downloaded from NASA ’s Earth Observing System Data and Infor-
mation System (EOSDIS, https://earthdata.nasa.gov ). 
Downloaded satellite data were preprocessed following the steps 
shown in Fig. 2. First, the satellite data were roughly subset using the 
lake boundary published by Ma et al. (2011) . Then, the Rayleigh- 
corrected reflectance (Rrc) and remote sensing reflectance (Rrs) were 
derived using the satellite signal in the solar spectrum correction scheme 
(6SV) (Vermote et al., 1997 ). Shen et al. (2020) proved the performance 
of the 6SV processor in large lakes of eastern China, based on compar -
isons with current popular atmospheric correction processors. The spe-
cific options of 6SV processor followed Shen et al. (2020) and are shown 
in the supplementary material (Text S1). The Chl-a and ZSD algorithms in 
ML_YHR lakes were developed based on random forest regression using 
OLCI Rrs data by Shen et al. (2020, 2022) . The Chl-a algorithm achieved 
high accuracy for eutrophic and turbid inland lakes across eastern China 
(R2 =0.73, RMSE =12.99 μg L�1, MAPE =36.91%) (Shen et al., 2022 ). 
The Chl-a algorithm was also validated by our measured data and 
showed high accuracy in ML_YHR lakes (R2 =0.82, RMSE =8.54 μg L�1, 
MAPE =29.61%, Fig. S2 a). The ZSD algorithm had high accuracy for 
eutrophic and turbid inland lakes across eastern China (R2 =0.70, 
RMSE =0.13 m, MAPE =33.43%) (Shen et al., 2020 ). The ZSD algorithm 
also showed high accuracy in ML_YHR lakes (R2 =0.84, RMSE =0.07 m, 
MAPE =14.07%, Fig. S2 b).

2.4. Model development and selection 
Field data samples and satellite data were matched based on 
geographic coordinates within a time difference of ±3 h. A total of 248 
pairs of matchups were obtained. The distribution of the main param -
eters in the matchups is consistent with the distribution of the total field 
dataset (Fig. S1 g-i), indicating that the matchup dataset is representa -
tive. Accordingly, 60% (N =150) of matchups were divided based on the 
concentration gradient and used as the model calibration set (CAL). The 
remaining 98 matchups were used as the model validation set (VAL). 
Satellite-derived independent variables were used in model develop -
ment in order to cancel uncertainties in satellite products as much as 
possible through regression coefficients. Before model development, 
independent variables with skewed distributions (skewness >2.0 and 
min/max ratio <0.1) were log-transformed to comply with the model ’s 
normality assumption. In our dataset, Chl-a and ZSD needed to be log- 
transformed. In addition, independent variables were standardized to 
suppress the correlation between each other. 
In a previous study, a combination of Chl-a, Tw, Kd, and AccuPAR 
could accurately estimate cCO2 in an eutrophic lake (Qi et al., 2020 ). In 
our dataset, cCO2 was also significantly correlated with ln(Chl- a), Tw, ln 
(ZSD), and AccuPAR (p <0.05), and Kd were highly correlated with ZSD 
(Zhang et al., 2020 ). Thus, a stepwise quadratic polynomial regression 
model was trained using ln(Chl- a), Tw, ln(ZSD), and AccuPAR as inde-
pendent variables (referred to in this research as Model1). 
Considering that AccuPAR may ignore the differences in received 
radiation between samples observed at different times in one field sur-
vey, time-related variables were added to improve model performance. 
The Akaike information criterion (AIC) was used to compare the good-
ness of fit between candidate models. The degree of interpretation of 
cCO2 variations by each model was compared by the coefficient of 
determination (R2). First, AccuPAR was replaced by instantaneous PAR 
variables (iPAR and aPAR). But the model performance did not improve (Table S1). Then we tested other combinations of these PAR-related 
variables. Only the combination of AccuPAR and iPAR improved AIC 
and R2 (Table S1). The corresponding quadratic polynomial model ob-
tained after stepwise regression was referred to as Model2. Based on 
Model2, other time-related variables (Ts, Drs, ks) were added to 
strengthen the estimation ability of samples observed at different times 
for a variety of targeted lakes. Since the AIC and R2 of models were all 
improved after adding these variables (Table S1), these three models 
remained as candidate models, referred to as Model3, Model 4, and 
Model5. Model3 (Drs) emphasizes the time to receive solar radiation. 
Model4 (Ts) emphasizes the absolute moment of observation. Model5 
(ks) focuses on characterizing the amount of radiation accumulated at 
the moment of observation. Furthermore, the candidate models were 
evaluated by the estimation accuracy of the calibration and validation 
sets. The final cCO2 estimation model was decided based on compre -
hensive comparisons of the model ’s goodness of fit, degree of interpre -
tation, and model performance. All models were constructed using the R 
v.4.0.5 (R is a language, and it is used in an environment for statistical 
computing, provided by the R Foundation for Statistical Computing, 
Vienna, Austria; URL https://www.R-project.org/ ). 
2.5. Model sensitivity analysis 
Monte Carlo simulation was used to evaluate the model ’s sensitivity 
to input variables ’ uncertainties. Uncertainties in each satellite-derived 
input variable were quantified based on the mean absolute relative error 
(MAPE ). The max MAPE of Chl-a was 36.91% in (Shen et al., 2022 ). The 
max MAPE of ZSD was 33.43% in (Shen et al., 2020 ). The MAPE of the Tw 
product was 5.20% (Fig. S3 d). The max MAPE of the PAR product was 
9.04% (Fig. S3 b, c). Considering these MAPE from published literature 
or the evaluation results of our dataset, conservative larger uncertainties 
of 40%, 10%, 40%, and 20% were defined for the satellite derived Chl-a, 
Tw, ZSD, and iPAR data, respectively. For each combination of input 
uncertainties, the Monte Carlo simulation ran 100,000 iterations for 
every 248 field-satellite matchups. For simulated variables <0 after the 
error was assigned, the simulations were reassigned to ensure the 
calculation of the model (Chl-a, 1; Tw, 1; ZSD, 0.01; iPAR, 100). Since 
AccuPAR was obtained by integrating the daily iPAR, we did not 
simulate its uncertainty separately but directly transferred the iPAR 
errors to it. The averaged results ranged from 5th to 95th based on 
100,000 simulation results used as the final simulation result to reduce 
the effect of extreme outliers on the simulation results. Statistics on the 
differences between the simulation results and original model outputs of 
all matchups were used to quantitatively evaluate the model ’s sensi-
tivity to the uncertainties of different input variables.

3.Results 
3.1. Selection of cCO 2 estimation model 
Of all the five candidate models, Model3 with the input combination 
of Chl-a, ZSD, Tw, iPAR, AccuPAR, and Drs showed the best overall 
performance (Table 2). Compared with Model1, in which variables 
related to observation time were omitted, other models had improved 
goodness of fit and degree of interpretation. At the same time, the 
complexity of the models also significantly increased with Model5 
having 20 equation terms, which is about twice as many as that found in 
the first three models. However, the model estimation accuracy for the 
calibration set did not significantly improve with the increase in vari-
ables. RMSE and MAPE of Model2 –5 had an improvement rating below 
15% compared to Model1. For the validation set, the estimation accu-
racy of Model4 and Moldel5 decreased, indicating overfitting. Although 
the estimation accuracy of models for the overall validation set did not 
drop significantly compared to the calibration set, the model perfor -
mance for validation samples in different seasons decreased with the 
lowest degree of interpretation recorded in the spring and winter (R2 <
0.5, Table 2). The RMSE of Model1 for the spring validation samples increased by 40% compared to the overall validation set. The perfor -
mance of Model2 and Model5 for summer samples also increased by 
over 30%. Only the RMSE of Model3 and Model4 increased <25% for 
each seasonal sample. For the winter validation samples, only the R2 of 
Model2 and Model3 is still 0.38. In summary, the performance of 
Model3 for the calibration set and the validation set was the best among 
the five models (R2 >0.38, RMSE <6.35 μmol L�1, MAPE <25.32%). 
The validation performance of Model3 for each season was also better 
than other five models. Combined with its performance in the AIC value 
and the number of equation terms, Model 3 was selected as the cCO2 
estimation model for lakes in the ML_YHR basins. The model ’s specific 
coefficients and statistical information are shown in Table S2. 
3.2. Model performance 
3.2.1. Performance for field surveys 
For field-satellite matchups, the model-estimated cCO2 showed good 
agreement with field-measured cCO2. They were distributed on both 
sides of the 1:1 line (R2 ≈0.7, RMSE <6.34 μmol L�1, and MAPE <
24.68% in Fig. 4). Model estimates showed a slight underestimation for 
samples with cCO2 larger than 30 μmol L�1. The mean daily cCO2 of 
samples from one sampling campaign in one lake (matched within one 
day) also showed good consistency (R2 ≈0.75, RMSE <4.32 μmol L�1, 
MAPE <31.10%, Fig. 4 b). Relative bias for surveys with low cCO2 (<
10 μmol L�1) were large because the average of limited samples was 
susceptible to outliers. For matchup samples from lakes in different 
trophic states (mesotrophic to highly eutrophic), model estimates also 
showed good performance (R2 >0.64, RMSE <6.85 μmol L�1, MAPE <
26.57%, Table S3). 
Estimated spatial cCO2 variations also agreed with the measured 
data and prior knowledge (Fig. 5). For lake estuary areas, our model 
estimated a lower cCO2 than other areas because of the lower Chl-a and 
Secchi disk depth (ZSD) resulting from river inflows (Fig. 5 Lake Hongze 
and Gaoyou). Surface cCO2 in shallow lakes would also elevate due to 
the vertical exchange of CO2-rich bottom water with sediment resus -
pension resulting from wind and wave disturbance in southeastern Lake

Compared with the multi-year spatiotemporal variation of cCO2 in 
Lake Taihu from 2016 to 2020 estimated by Aqua MODIS data using the 
model proposed by Qi et al. (2020) (Fig. 6 a, b), the results of our model 
were consistent but with lower estimates. Sentinel-3-derived cCO2 
showed more details in places like the northwestern small bay and the 
southwestern river mouth due to better spatial resolution of OLCI. Lower 
estimates mainly occurred in the southwestern areas during winter and 
spring according to the time series of four virtual stations (Fig. 6 f). 
These spatial differences between the two estimates may be due to the 
differences in observation times and uncertainties of satellite products. 
The time difference between Sentinel-3 and Aqua observations is about 
3 h. This will lead to differences in the spatial patterns of water quality in 
Lake Taihu (Qi et al., 2018 ; Chen et al., 2019b ), resulting in different 
cCO2 patterns. On the other hand, the lack of a critical band at 665 nm in 
the case of MODIS would lead to uncertainties in long-term MODIS Chl-a 
retrieval (Cao et al., 2022b ; Shen et al., 2022 ). Uncertainties of Aqua- 
derived Chl-a products (R2 =0.75, MAPE =25.3%, RMSE =10.6 μg 
L�1 (Shi et al., 2015a )) could lead to overestimations (Qi et al., 2020 ). 
The lower Chl-a in the southwestern area may also lead to a larger un-
certainty of Chl-a products, exacerbating the differences between the 
estimates of Aqua and Sentinel-3. Nevertheless, matchups in the four 
virtual stations of two estimates showed that although there were dif-
ferences in RMSE =28.22 μmol L�1 and MAPE =46.72%, the overall 
consistency was good (MR =1.03). These calculations proved that our

4.Discussion 
4.1. Why does our model work? 
The production and consumption processes of dissolved CO2 in lake 
surface water are mainly divided into endogenous and exogenous pro-
cesses as shown in Fig. 12. These factors and processes mainly includes: 
(a) the direct input of carbon (mainly DIC and DOC) from the river and 
land to the lake (Weyhenmeyer et al., 2015 ), (b) the balance of CO2 and 
other DIC species in the carbonate system (Marc ´e et al., 2015 ; Stets et al., 
2017 ), (c) the photochemical and microbial mineralization of dissolved 
organic matter in the water body, which produces CO2 (Tranvik et al., 
2009 ; Nydahl et al., 2019 ), (d) the mineralization of sediments that 
produce CO2 and exchange it from the bottom to surface through up-
welling (Ducharme-Riel et al., 2015 ; Reed et al., 2018 ), (e) the

15conditions, the biological respiration and metabolic intensity would be 
greater than the photosynthesis intensity, resulting in a higher cCO2 
(Kortelainen et al., 2006 ; Kosten et al., 2010 ; Marotta et al., 2014 ). In 
our cCO2 estimation model (Table S2), the previously mentioned effects 
of Chl-a on cCO2 were jointly constrained by Tw and ZSD through 
quadratic polynomial regression. The sensitivity analysis showed that 
ZSD was the most sensitive parameter in lakes tested (Table S4), which 
was different with the Taihu model where Chl-a was the most sensitive 
(Qi et al., 2020 ). It indicated that the effect of ZSD on photosynthesis in 
other less eutrophic lakes was greater than Chl-a, which was different 
from the highly eutrophic Lake Taihu. 
Similarly, in addition to being an indicator of the underwater light 
condition associated with algal photosynthesis (Deng et al., 2017 ; Qi 
et al., 2020 ), Secchi disk depth (ZSD) also has the potential to predict the 
physical mixing related to changes in cCO2 because the resuspensions of 
sediments are susceptible to water mixing in shallow lakes. Most of the 
lakes in the ML_YHR basins are shallow lakes (mean depth: 1.1–8.4 m), 
and the suspended particulate matter in lakes varies sharply (1–300 mg 
L�1) and is susceptible to resuspension events caused by hydrodynamic 
disturbances (Hou et al., 2017 ; Cao et al., 2020 ). Disturbances caused by 
river inputs and vertical mixing of lake water can significantly affect the 
dynamics of lake suspended matter, affecting ZSD (Liu et al., 2020 ; Shen 
et al., 2020 ). Both of these processes would increase surface cCO2 
(Marotta et al., 2014 ; Podgrajsek et al., 2015 ; Weyhenmeyer et al., 
2015 ), making ZSD an indicator of cCO2. Water temperature could 
significantly affect various biogeochemical processes in water bodies 
and is a recognized predictor of CO2 (Sobek et al., 2005 ; Marotta et al., 
2009 ; Kosten et al., 2010 ). In the estimated model (Table S2), Tw 
interacted with PAR and ZSD in addition to Chl-a, confirming its inter-
action with various biogeochemical processes in the lake. 
DOC quality changing with trophic states makes DOC an unstable 
predictor of cCO2 in lakes. DOC in lakes mainly originate from exoge -
nous (e.g., terrestrial inputs) and endogenous (e.g., phytoplankton) 
sources (Fig. 12). The exogenous DOC has been shown to be more 
bioactive and easier to be mineralized to CO2 (Weyhenmeyer et al., 
2012 ; K¨ohler et al., 2013 ). In boreal forest lakes or low-productivity 
lakes, where exogenous DOC from terrestrial inputs dominates, DOC 
and CDOM were good indicators of lake CO2 (Sobek et al., 2005 ; Ray-
mond et al., 2013 ; Klaus et al., 2019 ). The eutrophication would make 
refractory endogenous DOC contribute more to the total DOC pool 
(Kothawala et al., 2014 ; Wen et al., 2022 ), weakening the relationship 
between DOC and cCO2 in lakes. The relationship between DOC and CO2 
in China lakes was found insignificant in both a previous study (Wen 
et al., 2017 ) and our measured data (Fig. S4 and p >0.05). In the context 
of increasing global lake eutrophication (Wang et al., 2018 ; Hou et al., 
2022 ), selecting the more derivable indicators such as Chl-a or ZSD as 
input variables would be more beneficial for the cCO2 estimation model 
for regional lakes when satellite-derived DOC or CDOM products are not 
available (Kutser et al., 2015 ). Since indicators of organic matter com-
ponents and lake trophic states are usually optical active (e.g., CDOM 
absorption spectral indexes, CDOM fluorescence indexes) (Zhang et al., 
2017 ; Wen et al., 2022 ). It might be great help to develop remote sensing 
methods that allow lake classification into exogenous and endogenous 
classes and then choose appropriate algorithms for deriving cCO2 from 
space. 
4.2. Improvements and limitations 
Although our model has good overall performance, limitations still 
exist in some cases. Our model could explain about 70% of the variance 
of cCO2 with MAPE <25% for calibration and validation datasets (Fig. 4, 
Table 2). The remaining 30% of the unexplained variance may come 
from the inorganic carbon input of rivers, the CO2 production rate in 
sediments, and the decomposition rate of organic matter (Weyhenmeyer 
et al., 2015 ). Although we hypothesize that ZSD can indirectly indicate 
the effects of mixing between surface water and CO2-rich bottom water or river water, such complex hydrological processes may not be fully 
predicted by quadratic equations alone. In addition, the estimation ac-
curacy of our model decreases in winter and spring, with an R2 of only 
about 0.4. This may be because photosynthesis of algae has less impact 
on CO2 during periods of dormancy and germination of algae, resulting 
in a reduced degree of model interpretation of CO2 variation in these 
seasons. The model sensitivity analysis results showed that the model 
was most sensitive to the uncertainty of ZSD (Table S4), especially for a 
ZSD <0.3 m (Fig. 7). This suggested that the model may overfit the high 
cCO2 in a low ZSD case during calibration, which in turn leads to over-
estimated cCO2. Nevertheless, when comprehensively considering the 
uncertainties of all input variables, the relative deviation of the model ’s 
estimates was <25%, and the relative deviation was only 15.98% under 
the ideal accuracy of the input variable (Table S4), where no extreme 
abnormality has occurred. Based on the sensitivity analysis and statis -
tical metrics of the model calibration and validation results (Table 2), 
the estimated results of the model in this study could reflect reliable 
spatiotemporal variations of cCO2, with a small uncertainty of about 
25%, which is only half of the mean coefficient of variation of monthly 
cCO2. 
Adding time-related auxiliary variables to the model could also help 
improve the model performance, in addition to satellite-derived vari-
ables. In previous studies, the time differences between sampling sites 
over a single field survey was usually ignored, and each sampling site 
was used to represent lake cCO2 spatial variations. However, lake cCO2 
can vary dramatically on an hourly scale (Morales-Pineda et al., 2014 ; 
Xu et al., 2019 ; Qi et al., 2020 ). Ignoring the temporal differences be-
tween sampling sites can be misleading as the assumption is that the 
differences in cCO2 between sites consists only of spatial differences, 
which may hinder the development of the estimation model. For single 
lake studies, scheduled periodic sampling could mitigate this bias to a 
certain extent (Xiao et al., 2020 ; Yan et al., 2021 ) and enable developing 
of higher-accuracy models (Qi et al., 2020 ). However, in regional or 
global studies, it is difficult to confirm the exact observation times of 
sampling sites in different surveys. Thus, time-related deviations in 
samples may reduce the interpretation of critical cCO2 predictors, hin-
dering the development of high-performance models. In this study, 
adding time-related variables improved the model ’s AIC, R2, and RMSE 
performance in the calibration processes (Table 2). The model perfor -
mance for validation samples also significantly improved, with an 
overall RMSE reduction of 17% and a 28% for the spring samples. These 
results show that the addition of time-related variables is of great help to 
the development of an cCO2 estimation model for regional lakes. 
Moreover, it also proved that the time differences between sampling 
sites have a non-negligible effect on analyzing the spatial and temporal 
variation of the CO2 in the regional lakes. 
In the field-satellite matchup dataset used for model calibration and 
validation in this study, the Chl-a level was mesotrophic or eutrophic 
(26.97 ±21.34 μg L�1), while ZSD was at a low level compared with 
global lakes (0.36 ±0.18 m, with a conservative global estimate of 1.88 
±1.24 m (He et al., 2022 )). Therefore, the model in this study is theo-
retically applicable to eutrophic turbid lakes. For low-productivity lakes, 
the related biological processes affecting cCO2 are not dominated by 
algae. This type of lakes mainly act as the decomposition place of 
terrestrial organic matter, resulting in a better relationship between 
cCO2 and DOC and CDOM (Sobek et al., 2003 ). For deep-water lakes 
with a relatively steady mixing regime (Woolway and Merchant, 2019 ), 
it is difficult for sediment resuspension to occur, making the ZSD unable 
to predict CO2 variations resulting from vertical mixing. For saline lakes, 
the carbonate balance controlled by physical and chemical parameters 
such as water temperature and salinity may have more significant im-
pacts on cCO2 (Li et al., 2021 ), making the input variables of our model 
insufficient for predicting this process. Therefore, the basic assumptions 
of our model do not apply to the types of lakes mentioned in this 
paragraph, which can hinder the direct application of the model on a 
global scale. T. 16In addition to the uncertainty of the cCO2 estimation model itself, 
some potential cCO2 dynamics that optical remote sensing could not 
capture raised the uncertainty in the estimation of lake cCO2. For 
example, because optical sensors cannot acquire water-leaving infor-
mation under cloud cover, short-term and intense CO2 variations 
accompanying the clouds or precipitation would be missing (Ojala et al., 
2011 ). Similarly, optical sensors cannot acquire water-leaving infor-
mation under algal scums and aquatic vegetation, where potentially 
more dramatic dynamics in cCO2 have been reported (Bolpagni et al., 
2007 ; Ouyang et al., 2017 ). Algae and macrophytes have intense 
photosynthesis and consume lots of CO2 during their growth and 
development, while their residues decay and decompose thereby pro-
ducing a large amount of CO2 after they die. However, due to the 
shading or interference of algal scums and macrophytes to the acquisi -
tion of radiative information on lake water, it is difficult to derive the 
lake environment parameters correctly, which brings challenges to the 
remote sensing estimation of cCO2 in these areas. In this study, only 
about 10% of the pixels were masked as algal scums and macrophytes 
with a high frequency (>20%, Fig. S5). This indicates that the 
remaining 90% pixels represent the opportunity to evaluate cCO2 dy-
namics in ML_YHR lakes. Nevertheless, it is still necessary to develop 
new approaches to remotely estimate cCO2 in these masked areas to 
advance knowledge of lake CO2 dynamics in further research. 
4.3. Opportunities and challenges 
There may be dramatic spatiotemporal variations of lake cCO2 be-
tween lakes and within lakes (Fig. 9), which is hard to monitor through 
traditional discrete and low-frequency field samplings. The lack of suf-
ficient spatiotemporal coverage on global lakes has been an essential 
source of uncertainties in previous estimates of global lake CO2 emis-
sions (Raymond et al., 2013 ; Holgerson and Raymond, 2016 ). For the 
113 study lakes in the ML_YHR basins, a relative deviation of about 35% 
in the estimated mean value of cCO2 could occur if only one lake was 
selected to represent the entire number of regional lakes. Further 
consideration of cCO2 seasonal variations could cause the range of the 
estimated mean cCO2 to be close to three times the reference regional 
mean value (mean relative deviation: 61%, range: �91% to 186%), with 
significant uncertainties. Although there was a relative uncertainty of 
25% in the results based on our satellite estimation model, it was only 
about half of the mean potential uncertainty in the field-based estimates. 
The remote sensing approach has great potential in reducing un-
certainties of monitoring and evaluating CO2 emissions from regional or 
global lakes. 
Satellite remote sensing is one of the few approaches to monitoring 
highly heterogeneous regional or global lake CO2 dynamics at a rela-
tively low cost. It is difficult to eliminate the time difference between 
sampling sites during field sampling, and differences in CO2 between 
sampling sites often result from both temporal and spatial differences. 
Even for automated navigation samplings conducted by unmanned 
boats, three hours were needed to monitor a lake of about 40 km2 (Loken 
et al., 2019 ). The high-frequency lake CO2 emissions monitoring 
network could only obtain a rough overview of spatial patterns repre -
senting lake CO2 emissions; however, this overview came with high 
construction and maintenance costs (Lee et al., 2014 ). In contrast, sat-
ellite imaging time for large areas is instantaneous compared to field 
sampling. The average cost of satellite data is low because massive 
global data can be obtained after the launch. This study proved that 
adding time-related variables to the estimation model could mitigate the 
coupling of temporal differences in the field cCO2 data, which enabled 
the acquisition of a more realistic spatial variation of lake cCO2. In 
further research, more field-satellite matched data from multi-type lakes 
should be obtained with within a time difference less than three hours. 
Other satellite sensors, besides Sentinel-3 OLCI, have the potential to 
investigate lake CO2 emissions. For example, the Aqua MODIS data time 
series is over 20 years long. However, it is challenging to quantify pigments like Chl-a in inland waters because MODIS does not have 
spectral bands in the red part of the spectrum, which is critical to 
detecting Chl-a in inland and coastal waters (Cao et al., 2022b ). The 
Landsat series data can extend the observation to 1984 (nearly 40 years). 
Its high spatial resolution (30 m) is suitable for monitoring small lakes 
(1–10 km2), which cannot be mapped with moderate resolution sensors 
(e.g., MODIS, OLCI) (Palmer et al., 2015 ). However, the 8-bit radio -
metric resolution of sensors before Landsat-8 is not sufficient for map-
ping water quality parameters (Kutser, 2012 ). Moreover, considering 
the cloud cover, the longer revisit period of high-resolution satellites (e. 
g., Landsat ~16 days) does not allow data acquisition at a sufficient 
frequency (Klaus et al., 2019 ). However, Sentinel-2 allows lake sampling 
with a 5-day revisit time (with a shorter time at higher latitudes) and 
with high spatial resolution (10 m). Sentinel-2 has also proved it possible 
to map lake Chl-a and DOC (Toming et al., 2016 ). Thus, future research 
may rely on the virtual constellation of high-resolution satellites (e.g., 
Sentinel-2A and B, Landsat-8 and 9) to help overcome this problem (Cao 
et al., 2022a ). 
Different satellite sensors have accumulated massive earth observa -
tion data. However, applying this data for lake CO2 mapping is still 
challenging. More research is needed to make the full use of this data. 
Furthermore, the high-frequency data of geostationary satellites (e.g., 
CMOS, Himawari-8) should be used to further develop a spatiotempo -
rally coupled CO2 estimation model, which may help further eliminate 
the effects of time-related differences coupled in the field data. These 
improvements have the potential to significantly advance our under -
standing of the lake carbon cycle and correctly estimate lake carbon 
budgets although it will not be possible to use geostationary satellites at 
higher latitudes where most of the world lakes occur. 
Although the model proposed in this study cannot adequately cover 
all types of lakes due to insufficient field-satellite matched data in other 
regions, many lakes worldwide meet our model ’s theoretical assump -
tions, indicating its huge application potential. About 80% of global 
lakes have an average water depth of <5 m (Messager et al., 2016 ), 
similar to the lakes in the ML_YHR basins. They are easily disturbed by 
wind and waves, which aligns with the use of ZSD as an indicator of cCO2. 
In addition, >60% of global lakes are already eutrophic( Wang et al., 
2018 ), and the potential of Chl-a as an indicator of lake CO2 has also 
been confirmed in other eutrophic lakes with high productivity in 
America (Balmer and Downing, 2011 ; Pacheco et al., 2014 ) and Africa 
(Borges et al., 2022 ). The many achievements in using different satellite 
data to retrieve Chl-a and ZSD, or their related indicators in global lakes 
(He et al., 2022 ; Pahlevan et al., 2022 ) also provided good cause for 
further research. 
Further promotion and validation of our model on a global scale can 
lead to great opportunities and challenges. The promotion and expan -
sion of the authors ’ proposed model will open new doors to under -
standing carbon cycles of different types of lakes in climatic zones 
around the world; however, the model coefficients must be recalibrated 
to achieve this. The proposed model may even have to be re-retrained 
with more indicators. For example, in cold and low-productivity 
boreal lakes, the role played by the photosynthesis of phytoplankton 
may be replaced by the mineralization of organic matter (Sobek et al., 
2003 ). The dominant predictor of cCO2 would be DOC or in the case of 
remote sensing it’s coloured component, CDOM. For saline lakes similar 
to oceans, the effect of the carbonate balance on cCO2 is enhanced (Li 
et al., 2021 ), and salinity might be essential to the model to constrain the 
related process. 
With the development of high-precision satellite products featuring 
lake CO2 key factors and the acquisition of more field data, sophisticated 
algorithms developed with the help of machine learning (Chen et al., 
2019a ), and semi-analytical algorithms (Bai et al., 2015 ) have the great 
potential to develop cCO2 models with higher performance. It is even 
possible to establish a general cCO2 model for global lakes, leading to a 
more accurate estimation of global lake CO2 emissions. T. 175.Conclusions 
In this study, a stepwise quadratic polynomial cCO 2 estimation 
model for lakes in the ML_YHR basins was constructed using the field- 
measured cCO 2 data and the Sentinel-3-derived Chl-a, ZSD, Tw, iPAR, 
AccuPAR, and Drs as input variables. Satellite-derived Chl-a, ZSD, Tw, 
and PAR products are good cCO 2 predictors for lakes in the ML_YHR 
basins with conditions ranging from mesotrophic to highly eutrophic. 
Besides, adding time-related auxiliary variables to constrain the model 
also helped improve model performance. Our model was the most sen-
sitive to the uncertainty of ZSD products, indicating the dominant effect 
of ZSD on photosynthesis and mixing in regional meso-eutrophic shallow 
lakes. The reconstructed multi-year cCO 2 spatiotemporal dynamics of 
lakes in the ML_YHR basins showed dramatic seasonal variations, which 
were low in the summer and autumn but high in the winter and spring. 
The annual mean cCO 2 of ML_YHR lakes decreased with the increase in 
the eutrophication degree and with the decrease in lake sizes. This study 
is the first estimate and the reconstruction of multi-year cCO 2 covering 
regional lakes using satellite data, which proves the application poten -
tial of the remote sensing approach in large-scale lake CO2 emission 
estimations. In future research, field-satellite matched data from 
different types of lakes and more high-precision satellite-derived CO2 
indicators should be added to improve the model performance. We 
believe the remote sensing approach will contribute to further reducing 
uncertainty in global lake CO2 emission estimates. This contribution can 
also better track CO2 emissions and thereby add to the knowledge base 
needed to solve the eutrophication problem worldwide.

Deep-Sea Research I 55 (2008) 405–434
Satellite-driven modeling of the upper ocean mixed layer and
air–sea CO 2ﬂux in the Mediterranean Sea
Fabrizio D’Ortenzioa,/C3, David Antoinea, Salvatore Marullob
aLaboratoire d’Oceanographie de Villefranche, Universite ´Pierre et Marie Curie et CNRS, Quai de La Darse,
BP 8, 06238 Villefranche sur Mer Cedex, France
bCentro Ricerche Frascati, Ente per le Nuove tecnologie, l’Energia e l’Ambiente Frascati, Italy
Received 27 September 2006; received in revised form 30 November 2007; accepted 12 December 2007
Available online 14 January 2008
Abstract
The air–sea CO 2ﬂux, the carbon export to the deep layers, and more generally the carbon budgets are presently poorly
characterized in the Mediterranean Sea. An approach to the simulation of these ﬂuxes at regional scale is proposed, based
on an array of unconnected one-dimensional (1D) physical–biological–chemical coupled models. The rationale isto massively assimilate satellite information, on one hand to derive accurate surface heat ﬂuxes, and, on the other hand, to
implicitly account for the horizontal processes not explicitly represented in the 1D scheme. This method is applied here to
simulate the upper ocean physical and biogeochemical dynamics of the entire Mediterranean Sea over the years 1998–2004,and at a 0.5 1spatial resolution. The mixed-layer annual cycles are validated against the values determined from a database
ofin situ temperature proﬁles, demonstrating the validity of the approach in various physical regimes. A validation of the
simulated annual cycles of the total inorganic carbon (TCO
2) and of the carbon dioxide partial pressure ( pCO2)i s
presented at a measurement site in the northwestern Mediterranean where both properties were determined in 1998–1999and in 2003–2004. An additional validation of the pCO
2ﬁelds is presented using along-track data collected during the
‘‘Productivite ´des Syste `mes Oce ´aniques Pe ´lagiques’’ (PROSOPE) cruise. The basin-scale air–sea carbon budget derived
from the model outputs shows that the Mediterranean Sea, over the study period, is close to equilibrium with theatmosphere, with a slight sink for the atmospheric CO
2. This is in agreement with the results previously obtained via
indirect methods and is supported here by a series of sensitivity studies. A detailed analysis of the pCO2and TCO 2seasonal
distributions in the Mediterranean Sea is provided for the ﬁrst time. It shows that the biological processes play a major rolein shaping the pCO
2seasonal evolution in the eastern and western basins.
