Keywords: CO2dynamics; Ocean remote sensing; Mediterranean Sea; Ocean mixed layer
1. Introduction
The Mediterranean Sea is subject to a growing
anthropogenic pressure; in addition, the relativelysmall size of this sea may emphasize or accelerate
the effects of the atmospheric CO 2augmentation on
its climate, as compared with the rest of the planet
(Bethoux et al., 1999 ;IPCC, 2001 ). The evolution of
the atmospheric CO 2is regulated by the ocean,
primarily through the ‘‘solubility pump’’ (physicalentrainment of CO
2-rich waters to the deep ocean),
and also through the ‘‘biological pump’’ (sinking ofARTICLE IN PRESS
www.elsevier.com/locate/dsri
0967-0637/$ - see front matter r2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
doi:10.1016/j.dsr.2007.12.008/C3Corresponding author. Tel.: +33 4 93 76 37 15;
fax: +33 4 93 76 37 39.
E-mail address: dortenzio@obs-vlfr.fr (F. D’Ortenzio).particulate organic carbon or physical entrainment
of dissolved organic carbon). Both these mechan-
isms contribute to modiﬁcation of the carbon
content within the water column and then the CO 2
exchange at the air–sea interface. In the Mediterra-nean Sea, the response of the ecosystems toalterations of the physical and biological environ-ments is expected to be important ( Duarte et al.,
1999), although presently largely undetermined.
In this context, the Mediterranean Sea is a key
area where our understanding of the mechanisms
and feedbacks controlling the Earth’s climate couldbe improved, and where our capability to predictthe responses to various scenarios of future envir-onment changes can be tested ( Turley, 1999 ). In this
sea, the physical and biogeochemical processescover a wide range of temporal and spatial scales.Dynamics are controlled by two thermohaline cells
(one for each sub-basin, the eastern and the
western), both driven by the winter dense waterformation occurring in speciﬁc areas such as thenorthwestern basin and the northeastern Levantine,and by the spreading and modiﬁcation of theAtlantic water from its inﬂow through the GibraltarStrait toward the eastern basin. The surfacecirculation and the mixed-layer evolution are
extremely dynamic as a consequence of the varia-
bility of the atmospheric forcing and of animportant mesoscale activity ( D’Ortenzio et al.,
2005). A wide range of biological regimes is present,
with phytoplankton blooms in the NW Mediterra-nean, the Alboran region and the South Adriatic,whereas the rest of the basin is prevalentlyoligotrophic ( Bosc et al., 2004 ). The limiting
nutrients differ in the two sub-basins—nitrate in
the west and phosphate in the east ( Allen et al.,
2002).
Recent measurements at Gibraltar indicate that
the Mediterranean Sea would be a sink of organiccarbon from, and a source of inorganic carbon to,the Atlantic Ocean ( Dafner et al., 2001 ). The
interannual and the sub-basin budgets are uncer-
tain, however, except in a few, well-sampled, areas
(Copin-Monte ´gut et al., 2004 ). How the physical
and biological processes modulate the exchange ofCO
2at the air–sea interface is presently unknown,
as well as the role of the Mediterranean Sea as asource or a sink for atmospheric CO
2. In summary,
carbon budgets are presently poorly constrained inthe Mediterranean. Basin-scales estimates of the
CO
2air–sea ﬂux in the Mediterranean have been
produced only by indirect methods, as a residualafter all others terms of the carbon budget are
determined. In particular, Copin-Monte ´gut (1993)
determined a weak sink for the atmospheric CO 2,
with a climatological integrated ﬂux of 0.35–1.85/C210
12mole per year. A large uncertainty,
however, is attached to the magnitude and directionof this ﬂux.
The difﬁculty lies in the poor sampling of
the Mediterranean for the parameters of thecarbonate system. The few published measurements
are essentially from the western Mediterranean, in
particular the Dynamique des Flux Atmosphe ´riques
en Me ´diterrane ´e(DYFAMED) site in the Ligurian
sea ( Marty, 2002 ), and in the Gibraltar region
(Santana-Casiano et al., 2002 ;Sempere et al., 2003 ).
As a consequence, the results of Copin-Monte ´gut
(1993) have never been re-visited, and, more
importantly, the temporal and spatial variability
of the air–sea CO
2exchange at the scale of the entire
Mediterranean has never been estimated.
Large-scale observations provided by satellite
ocean remote sensing may help tackle the problem.For instance, the CO
2air–sea exchange can be
estimated through empirical relationships linkingthe CO
2partial pressure ( pCO2) or the CO 2fugacity
(fCO2) to sea-surface temperature (SST) or chlor-
ophyll concentration (Chl). Such relationships are
derived from regional in situ data sets and are
applied at local or global scales using satellite SSTand Chl. This approach can retrieve the marinepCO
2with an acceptable accuracy ( Cosca et al.,
2003;Levefre et al., 2002 ;Metzl et al., 1999 ), but its
application outside of the time–space domain inwhich it was developed is controversial, essentially
because its empirical nature cannot, by deﬁnition,
lead to any predictive skill. In the Mediterranean,Me´mery et al. (2002) found signiﬁcant correlations
between CO
2and SST or Chl in summertime only,
which demonstrates de facto the inapplicability of
this simpliﬁed empirical satellite approach in thisarea. They also concluded that, although SST andChl are two important proxies to estimate carbon
dynamics, a realistic simulation of the CO
2seasonal
cycles requires that the ‘‘history’’ of the watercolumn be known, which is not feasible throughempirical methods. Therefore, a modeling approachis needed to reproduce the physical state andevolution of the ocean and the biogeochemistry ofthe water column.
Such an approach has been used to characterize
the marine carbon cycle at global scale ( Sarmiento
and Le Quere, 2003 ), but not for the Mediterranean.ARTICLE IN PRESS
F. D’Ortenzio et al. / Deep-Sea Research I 55 (2008) 405–434 406Global circulation models, coupled with ecosystems
models, were successfully used to describe the
physical and biological dynamics of the Mediterra-
nean ( Crise et al., 1999 ;Crispi et al., 1999 ). To our
knowledge, however, the speciﬁc issue of the air–seaCO
2exchange and carbon export has never been
addressed except through one-dimensional (1D)modeling studies at speciﬁc sites, where data areavailable (i.e., at the DYFAMED site; Andersen
and Prieur, 2000 ;Le´vy et al., 1998 ;Me´mery et al.,
2002).
In summary, the insufﬁcient number of measure-
ments and the inadequacy of the empirical remote-sensing algorithms precluded an experimentalcharacterization of the carbon dynamics in theMediterranean Sea, which in turn prevented the set-up of suitable and efﬁcient CO
2-dedicated basin-
scale models.
Another approach is used here, which can be
considered as an intermediate solution between thepurely empirical remote-sensing approach and themore complex simulations carried out throughcoupled general circulation models. A number ofunconnected 1D grid cells are put side by side inorder to cover the Mediterranean Sea. In each cell, a1D coupled physical–biogeochemical model is run
(Antoine and Morel, 1995a, b , AM95 hereafter),
using satellite-derived information for forcing asmuch as possible. When such data are unavailable,data from weather forecast models are used instead(see later for an outline of the AM95 model). TheAM95 model, precisely designed to use satellite dataas input, was validated at an open ocean station(Ocean Weather Station Papa in the NE Paciﬁc), yet
it was not fully exploited because of the unavail-
ability of ocean color sensors at the time of the work(end of the Coastal Zone Color Scanner Mission in1986). The situation has evolved since the launch ofa new generation of ocean color sensors, includingin particular the NASA Sea-viewing Wide Field-of-view Sensor (SeaWiFS; McClain et al., 1998 ).
This new data set, combined with other satellite
remote-sensing observations (see later), allows
here the AM95 approach to be fully developedand tested to estimate the CO
2ﬂuxes in the
Mediterranean Sea.
Such a ‘‘satellite-driven’’ approach is a compro-
mise relative to other approaches inasmuch as (1) anaccurate modeling of the mixed-layer dynamics ispreserved, (2) the water-column biomass is not
explicitly modeled through a multi-box food-web
model (such as ‘‘NPZD’’ models), but is ratherinferred from the satellite chlorophyll concentration
used as a proxy, and (3) satellite data are either used
as forcing or assimilated rather than being simply
considered as validation tools.
The extensive use of satellite data allows mitiga-
tion of possible adverse effects related to the purely1D approach. A minor impact of the 1D assump-tion is expected on the biological compartment ofthe model, which is a diagnostic model forcedentirely by the satellite surface observations (see
later the model description). The biomass laterally
or vertically advected is, at least partially, implicitlyaccounted for in the local carbon budgets, thanks tothe assimilation of the satellite chlorophyll.
Lateral advection can signiﬁcantly inﬂuence the
upper ocean density ﬁeld in some regions, so thephysical simulation of the surface layers might bemore sensitive to the 1D assumption. The realism of
the simulation of the upper ocean physics is,
however, crucial for the subsequent steps of themodeling (i.e., the biological and chemical compart-ments). Therefore, the ﬁrst part of the paperessentially focuses on the physical segment of themodel, and the results are examined with somedetails at local and basin scale. Particular attentionwas devoted to the evaluation of the air–sea heat
and momentum ﬂuxes, which drive the physical
compartment of the model. Once again, an exten-sive use of satellite data was preferred to calculatethe heat ﬂuxes and the wind stress.
In the second part of the paper, the outputs of
the simulations are analyzed to (1) investigate thespatial and temporal variability of the pCO
2in
the basin, (2) produce a ﬁrst basin-scale carbon
budget that is not derived by indirect methods, and
(3) evaluate the respective roles of several processesin controlling the total carbon content evolution.Sensitivity studies are also carried out to evaluatethe robustness of the basin-scale air–sea CO
2ﬂux
and carbon export estimations to various para-meters or parameterizations.
2. Outline of the AM95 1D model
Only the main features of the model are brieﬂy
described below, and the reader is referred to AM95for a detailed description, sensitivity analyses, and avalidation at the Ocean Weather Ship Station Papa(NE Paciﬁc). The selection of model parametersis described in Section 4.3. The four modules of
the AM95 model, which are successively run at
different temporal resolutions (see below, after theARTICLE IN PRESS
F. D’Ortenzio et al. / Deep-Sea Research I 55 (2008) 405–434 407description of the modules themselves) are:
(1) A turbulent kinetic energy (TKE) model
(Gaspar et al., 1990 ), driven by surface heat
ﬂuxes (i.e., solar: Qs, long-wave: Qb, latent: Qe,
and sensible: Qh) and wind stress, and using an
eddy diffusivity parameterization of the turbu-lent ﬂuxes. The effect of the chlorophyll biomasson the heating rate of the water column isaccounted for following Morel and Antoine
(1994) . The depth resolution is 5 m down to
the lower boundary of the model domain(nominally 300 m; see, however, the sensitivitystudies later on). The mixed-layer depth (MLD)is determined as the depth where the eddykinetic energy falls below a threshold of2/C210
/C06m/C02s/C02.
(2) A depth-, time-, wavelength-resolved phyto-
plankton photosynthetic carbon ﬁxation model
(primary production model; Morel, 1991 ),
driven by the chlorophyll concentration andthe photosynthetically available radiation at thesea surface. Spectral resolution is 20 nm withinthe visible range, time resolution is one-tenth ofthe day length (so close to 1 h), and depthresolution is 5 m down to the bottom of the
productive layer, which is computed as 1.5 times
the euphotic depth (i.e., the depth where thedownward photosynthetically available radia-tion is reduced to 1% of its value just beneaththe surface). The model uses a vertical chlor-ophyll proﬁle derived from the surface concen-tration ( Morel and Berthon, 1989 ). This method
produces a deep chlorophyll maximum, which
is a recurrent feature in the Mediterranean
(Crise et al., 1999 ). However, when the water
column is mixed (i.e., MLD larger than euphoticdepth), the chlorophyll concentration is con-sidered uniform throughout the mixed layer,with a constant value equal to the surface value.After integration over the three dimensions(depth, time, and wavelength), this model
provides the daily net carbon ﬁxation rates by
autotrophs ( P), for the mixed layer and the
layers below.
(3) A carbon export model, which assesses the fate
ofP. This module combines Pwith the observed
time variations of the water-column carboncontent (itself derived from the observed changeof the chlorophyll content through a carbon-to-
chlorophyll ratio), which allows a daily carbon
loss ( L) to be estimated. All possible conﬁgura-tions as regards the relative values of Pand L
are considered, and Lis then partitioned
between local recycling of organic carbon and
export to deeper levels by means of the f-ratio
(Eppley and Peterson, 1979 ). This method
allows the new production to be decoupledfrom the export of carbon on short time scales(i.e., a few days), while they are reconciledover an annual cycle. It is worth noting that theexported carbon implicitly exits the model
domain, so that remineralization is supposed
to take place only within the deep reservoir.
(4) A chemical module, which assess the impact of
the processes described in (1–3) on the evolutionof the total carbon content (TCO
2) and of the
pCO2in the water column. The possible change
in total alkalinity (TA) due to nitrate uptake(Goldman and Brewer, 1980 ) as well as the
changes in TCO
2and TA due to the formation
of calcium carbonate are also considered. Totalalkalinity can also be modulated by salinityvariations, if any. The pCO
2is ﬁnally computed
using the relevant equations and constants ofthe carbonate chemistry ( Goyet and Poisson,
1989;UNESCO, 1987 ). Along with the TCO
2
changes, the oxygen evolution is stoichiometri-
cally derived from the estimates of the new and
recycled production. Nitrate variations are alsoderived by using a C-to-N Redﬁeld ratio. Theseconcentrations, however, are never used toconstrain the modeling of the biological activity;they conversely are outputs of the simulation.Note that exchange of chemical species isallowed with an underlying deep reservoir where
all chemical species are assumed to be constant
over time. At the end, the carbon, oxygen, andnitrate ﬂuxes resulting from eddy diffusivity,air–sea exchange and export of organic carbonare computed.
The way these four modules are successively run
is as follows:
(1) The TKE model is run at a time resolution of
15 min over the entire study period. Then itsoutputs are averaged in order to produce dailyquantities (MLD, temperature, salinity, andeddy diffusivity coefﬁcients). After this aver-aging, the mixed layer is assumed to berigorously homogeneous. As a consequence,
the quantities exchanged through its lower and
upper boundaries are ‘‘instantaneously’’ sharedARTICLE IN PRESS
F. D’Ortenzio et al. / Deep-Sea Research I 55 (2008) 405–434 408by all parts of the mixed layer. Depth resolution
is kept unchanged below the mixed layer.
(2) The primary production model is run over the
entire study period at its own resolution(see point 2 above), providing the time seriesof the daily Pvalues. An input from module (1)
is the MLD, which is compared with the depthof the euphotic layer to determine the shape ofthe chlorophyll vertical proﬁle.
(3) The daily quantities produced in steps (1) and
(2) are used as inputs of modules (3) and (4),
which are also run at a 1-day time resolution.
The AM95 model is essentially controlled by
surface parameters, and is intended to evolvewithout any restoring processes, through assimila-tion of satellite-derived surface information. Verti-cal proﬁles of physical and chemical parameters are
needed only for the initialization. This restriction
conforms to the aim of developing a tool adapted tothe use of satellite data. Along the same line, thechlorophyll biomass is not a product of thesimulation, but is conversely an input to the primaryproduction model, and the corresponding datasource is expected to be an ocean color sensor.
3. The surface physical forcing: a satellite approach
The rationale in this work is to compute surface
heat ﬂuxes using bulk formulas, which are fed asoften as possible by satellite data. The use of a bulkformula is abandoned to compute Q
s, and satellite-
derived ﬂuxes are directly used. Details of theseselections are provided below. The upper-layer
chlorophyll concentration must also be known,
because the effect of the biomass on the heating rateof the water column is accounted for in the model.
3.1. Short wave radiation, Q
s
It has been often pointed out that the use of the bulk
formulas in the Mediterranean leads to an over-
estimation of Qs(Gilmann and Garrett, 1994 ;Tragou
and Lascaratos, 2003 ), and various corrective factors
were proposed. A deﬁnitive bulk parameterization ofQ
si s ,h o w e v e r ,s t i l lm i s s i n g .I nt h i ss t u d y ,w eh a v eu s e d
satellite—(METEOSAT)-derived Qsﬂuxes ( Brisson
et al., 1999, 1994 ), which have been shown to better
reproduce the dynamics observed in the ﬁeld data(Eymard et al., 2003 ) than bulk formulae.
Seven years (1998–2004) of these data for the
Mediterranean area were obtained from the ‘‘Centrede Me ´te´reologie Spatiale de Meteo France’’. They
are at a 3 km spatial resolution and with a temporal
resolution of 2 h. They have been remapped on the
European Center for Medium Range Weather Fore-cast(ECMWF) grid (see later on), and interpolated
to the ECMWF hours (0, 6, 12, 18 GMT), asdescribed in Eymard et al. (2003) .
3.2. Selection of the bulk formula for Q
b,Q e, and Q h
The Mediterranean is often used as a test basin
for the selection of the best-performing heat ﬂuxparameterizations because, in a steady state, the netheat loss through the strait of Gibraltar should becompensated by the air–sea surface gain. Thisbudget closure allows parameterizations of thedifferent heat ﬂux components to be tested ( Dietrich
et al., 2004 ;Gilmann and Garrett, 1994 ;Krahmann
et al., 2000 ;Tragou and Lascaratos, 2003 ).
On this basis, Castellari et al. (1998) proposed an
‘‘optimal’’ scheme for the computation of surfaceheat ﬂuxes for the Mediterranean Sea. This schemeincludes the parameterizations of Reed (1977) for
Q
s,May (1986) forQb, and Kondo (1975) forQh
and Qe. The wind stress is calculated from surface
winds using the Hellerman and Rosenstein (1983)
formula. This scheme was slightly modiﬁed by
Pinardi et al. (2003) , by replacing May’s formula
by the Bignami et al. (1995) formula for Qb. This
modiﬁed scheme was used here to compute the heatand momentum ﬂuxes. The inputs to this set of bulkformulae are now presented.
3.3. Selection of the relevant input parameters
3.3.1. Air and dew point temperatures and SST
The air and dew point temperatures were taken
from the 0.5 1resolution ECMWF analysis ( Jakob
et al., 2000 ), which are provided at 4 standard times,
i.e., 0, 6, 12, and 18 GMT. An evaluation of thequality of these data is provided in the Appendix.
In the Castellari et al. (1998) scheme, SST was a
blended product of satellite and in situ data
(Reynolds and Smith, 1995 ). Various authors,
however, have pointed out that satellite-derivedtemperatures could be more appropriate to derivesurface heat ﬂuxes ( Caniaux et al., 2005 ;Clayson
and Curry, 1996 ;Xue et al., 2000 ) because they are
closer to skin temperatures than any other source ofdata. Consequently, the Pathﬁnder Sea Surface
Temperature (PFSST) satellite data ( Kilpatrick
et al., 2001 ) have been used in the present work.ARTICLE IN PRESS
F. D’Ortenzio et al. / Deep-Sea Research I 55 (2008) 405–434 409These data are available as global daily SST maps at
4 km spatial resolution. Consequently, interpola-
tions were needed to match the spatial (0, 6, 12, and
18 GMT) and temporal (half a degree) resolution ofthe other forcing data sets. The diurnal cycle wasreconstructed as in Gentemann et al. (2003) , which
allows the SST to be derived at any time of the dayfrom its value at 0 GMT, given the irradiance andthe wind intensity (taken from the other forcingdata sets). An optimal interpolation was applied to
the PFSST data to produce gap-free daily maps
from the night passage, as described in Bretherthon
et al. (1976) andSantoleri et al. (1991) . Remaining
data gaps (clouds) were ﬁlled with a simple boxaverage. An assessment of the accuracy of theseinterpolated PFSST data is provided in Appendix.
3.3.2. Wind speed
In the Mediterranean, comparisons of the outputs
of weather forecasting models with in situ data have
shown that the wind direction is well simulated,whereas the intensity in near gale and gale condi-tions is less accurate (wind speeds greater than14/16 m s
/C01)(Bozzano et al., 2002 ). Satellite-derived
winds (e.g., QuikSCAT) provide a suitable alter-native because of their accuracy in a wide range of
wind conditions ( Draper and Long, 2002 ). Their use
is, however, limited by their low temporal resolution(/C243 days) and by their restricted availability (only
from July 1999 to 2002).
In order to produce realistic wind estimations
with a suitable temporal resolution, a speciﬁcmerging procedure between ECMWF and QuikSCATdata was developed ( Ruti et al., 2007 ), as adapted
from Mertens and Schott (1998) . The rationale is to
blend the ECMWF analysis data, which provide a6-h time resolution that is important for a correctsimulation of the mixed layer, and the QuikSCATdata, which provide a correction for high windspeeds whereas their temporal resolution is onlyabout 3 days. Details of the blending method can befound in Ruti et al. (2007) , and the QuikSCAT-to-
ECMWF conversion speciﬁcally used in this study
is presented in the Appendix.
3.4. Sea-surface chlorophyll concentration
The upper ocean chlorophyll concentrations
derived from the ocean color observations of theSeaWiFS sensor by using the global OC4V4
algorithm ( O’Reilly et al., 1998 ) have been shown
to be overestimated in summer and fall ( Bosc et al.,2004;D’Ortenzio et al., 2002 ). The cause for this
bias is not deﬁnitely identiﬁed (but see, e.g.,
Claustre et al., 2002 ), and several regional algo-
rithms have been proposed, as being supposedlymore adapted than the standard SeaWiFS proces-sing. The data set produced from the Bosc et al.
(2004) regional algorithm has been used here, which
has in particular the capability of deriving realisticconcentrations in summer ( o0.1 mg(Chl) m
/C03).
4. Setup of the basin-scale AM95 simulation in the
Mediterranean Sea
4.1. The spatial grid
An array of AM95 models encompassing the
whole Mediterranean basin has been set up, whichwill be referred to as the D’Ortenzio–Antoine
Matrix (DOAM hereafter). This array has a
resolution of 0.5 1in latitude and 0.5 1in longitude,
which is imposed by the coarsest resolution of theforcing data set, i.e., that of the ECMWF data. Thedomain does not include shallow waters withbottom depths less than 300 m, where the perfor-mance of satellite observations is poor, and thedynamics of the water column are generally too
complex to be simulated with a purely 1D approach.
The number of grid points is, therefore, 729 andrepresents 88% of the basin area.
4.2. The initializing data
The MEDAR/MEDATLAS ( Medar Group,
2002) winter climatological vertical proﬁles of
salinity and temperature were used as initial
conditions for each DOAM box. A linear inter-polation is performed to resample these data onthe model vertical grid (i.e., 5-m resolution).The initial vertical proﬁles for oxygen and nitrateswere also derived from MEDAR/MEDATLASdatabase.
Initial TCO
2and TA vertical proﬁles were
derived from the MEDAR/MEDATLAS climato-
logical salinity proﬁles using the relationshipsderived by Copin-Monte ´gut and Be ´govic (2002)
using data collected at the DYFAMED site. Wespeciﬁcally used their Eq. (4), which predicts TAwith a standard deviation of 1.8 mmol kg
/C01, and
their Eq. (6) for TCO 2, for which they did not report
the standard deviation. Other authors have pro-
posed similar regressions, using data collected in
different regions of the basin ( Copin-Monte ´gut,ARTICLE IN PRESS
F. D’Ortenzio et al. / Deep-Sea Research I 55 (2008) 405–434 4101993;Santana-Casiano et al., 2002 ). The TA–salinity
relationships derived from these studies all
match, whereas the TCO 2–salinity relationships
differ notably, mainly because of the effect of thebiological processes, which modify the surfaceconcentrations in different ways according to theregions and seasons. These relationships agreebetter when only deep values (depths greater than300 m) are considered, i.e., where biological pro-cesses are negligible. Consequently, the DOAM
simulations were initialized with TCO
2vertical
proﬁles derived only from winter salinity data,assuming that the water column is well mixed in thatperiod and that the TCO
2–salinity relationship of
Copin-Monte ´gut and Be ´govic (2002) for the deep
layers is representative of the average winterconditions in the Mediterranean. The resultinginitial ﬁelds for the mixed layer and the deep
reservoir are displayed in Fig. 1 , showing an
important east–west gradient in both the TA andTCO
2ﬁelds, with the highest values located in the
oriental basin. Finally, the atmospheric pCO2was
derived from monthly measurements of CO 2con-
centration at the Lampedusa Island ( Chamard
et al., 2003 ) and from the corresponding sea level
pressure data from ECMWF. The resulting pCO2cycle was then uniformly applied throughout the
Mediterranean.
4.3. Model parameters
The model parameters are as speciﬁed in AM95,
except for the light-photosynthesis model, whichincludes the photo-physiological parameters pro-posed in Morel et al. (1996) , and for the f-ratio. The
daily values of this ratio are here modulated as afunction of the surface chlorophyll concentration,
with the constraint that the average value over a
year in each grid cell is equal to the value predictedfrom the annual primary production in this cell,following Eppley and Peterson (1979) . The resulting
average is 0.27 for the western basin and 0.19 for theeastern basin.
The simulations are carried out over a period for
which all the necessary forcing data were available,
i.e., from 1998 to 2004, and include a spin-up period
of 2 years (year 1998 being run twice before startingthe 1998 year).
When surface heat ﬂuxes are computed, satellite
SST (PFSST) is used instead of the model SST eachtime the absolute difference between the twoexceeds 0.5 1C. The a priori objective of this dataARTICLE IN PRESS

5.1. Basin-scale heat budgets
The annual averages of each of the four terms of
the air–sea heat exchange, as computed over thewhole DOAM domain, are presented in Table 1 .
The interannual variability of the four heat ﬂux
terms and of the resulting net heat ﬂux is weak,except for the year 2003, because of the strongmidsummer heat wave that occurred at that time.
The present heat ﬂuxes are close to those of
Castellari et al. (1998) . The average Q
tot
(/C01.98 W m/C02) is close to zero. This value differs
slightly from the estimate of MacDonald et al.
(1994) (/C05.271.3 W m/C02), which was used by
Castellari et al. (1998) in their ‘‘budget closure’’
computations. The Qtotobtained here is closer to
the Gilmann and Garrett (1994) evaluation
(/C00.371.1 W m/C02), which was calculated with a
modiﬁed Reed’s formula to assess the impact of theaerosols on Q
s. The discrepancies with previous
estimates of Qtotare essentially due to the signiﬁcant
differences in the Qsand Qeterms.
Tragou and Lascaratos (2003) proposed an
average Qsof 185 W m/C02for the Mediterranean,
calculated using a 20-year time series of solarradiation measurements. This value is very closeto the Gilmann and Garrett (1994) estimation
(183 W m
/C02) and not far from the Meteosat
computation adopted here (173.6 W m/C02).
The aim here was not to a priori improve the
derivation of the heat ﬂuxes by proposing newformulations, but to derive them using an existing,widely used scheme along with satellite data whenavailable. The individual terms and the budgets are
slightly different from previous estimates, which
were, however, calculated from long-term averages
of oceanographic data, whereas the values providedhere were estimated over only 7 years.

The time evolution of the SST averaged over the

is not observed in the corresponding satellite SST.The maximum difference is observed in the winterof 2002 (about 1 1C).
Winter and summer averages were mapped
for both the model outputs and the observations(Fig. 3 ), showing an overall good agreement
(o11C) as well as some local differences. In
summer, a 1 1C overestimation is observed in the

Adriatic and in the Aegean Basin, and warmer(E11C) in the Alboran Sea region.
The model is able to capture important features
of the mean Mediterranean SST ﬁeld. The coldest
region of the basin, the NW Mediterranean, is well
reproduced both in summer and in winter, as well asthe SST ﬁeld in the Levantine Basin, with thehighest temperatures of the area. The patchydistribution of the eastern basin in winter (e.g., thecold feature observed in the Rhodes region; Fig. 3 ,

layer of the Mediterranean Sea are, on average,controlled mainly by air–sea exchange and biology(both about 40%), whereas the mixing term has asmaller impact, because of the relatively shallowmaximum depths reached in winter in the Mediter-
ranean. The largest differences between the two sub-
basins are observed in summer, with the air–seaexchange being the dominant process in the east,while biology still dominates in the west.
7. Conclusion
The upper ocean carbon dynamics of the entire
Mediterranean Sea was simulated for the period
1998–2004 with an array of 1D coupled physical–biogeochemical models ( Gaspar et al., 1990 ;An-
toine and Morel, 1995a ). The surface heat ﬂuxes
and wind stress were derived mostly from satelliteobservations, including SST, shortwave irradiation,wind speed, and ocean color. Particular attentionwas devoted to the computation of these ﬂuxes,
which allowed 7-year simulations to be performed
freely without any restoring to observations.
The simulated SST and MLD ﬁelds agree well
with observations ( Figs. 4–7 ). The main physical
features of the upper layers are reproduced, both interms of seasonal and interannual variability and interms of the extent of the stratiﬁcation and mixingevents. The absence of important drifts in the model
outputs indicates that the SST and MLD in the
Mediterranean Sea are weakly inﬂuenced by hor-izontal processes, at least when limited temporalperiods (7 years here) are considered. This resulta posteriori conﬁrms the usefulness and validity of
the 1D approach, which was a priori formulated
because (1) strong horizontal velocities are rarelyobserved in the Mediterranean Sea ( Millot, 1999 ;
Robinson and Golnaraghi, 1995 ), except in mesos-
cale features, which are out of the scope of thisstudy, and (2) it can be realistic as far as surfaceprocesses are concerned and the horizontal resolu-tion is coarse enough, as already stated by severalauthors ( Dutkiewicz et al., 2001 ;Lascaratos et al.,
1993;Vivier et al., 2002 ;Williams et al., 2000 ).
A successful validation of the TCO
2and pCO2
values was performed at a ﬁxed station (DYFA-
MED) and along a transect (PROSOPE cruise).ARTICLE IN PRESS
F. D’Ortenzio et al. / Deep-Sea Research I 55 (2008) 405–434 427Discrepancies occur locally, however (Alboran Sea
for instance), which might still be due to some
inappropriateness of the 1D assumption, as well as
to inappropriate parameterization of the biologicalsegment, in particular the f-ratio (as highlighted
by the sensitivity analyses ). The biological compart-
ment of the model should be little affected by ignoringadvection, because the biomass evolution is directlytaken from satellite observations. Nevertheless,when the horizontal velocities are not negligible, the
lateral transport of carbon can be important
enough to substantially modify the TCO
2and pCO2
ﬁelds. To our knowledge, however, the impact of
the lateral transport of heat and carbon on thesurface dynamic has never been examined in theMediterranean Sea.
The standard simulation indicates that the
Mediterranean is close to equilibrium with the
atmosphere, with, however, a small sink for
the atmospheric CO
2. This result is coherent with
previous studies ( Copin-Monte ´gut, 1993 ) based on
carbon budgets of the basin, and is supported by theresults of the sensitivity analyses carried out here.All but two sensitivity runs agree on the sign of theair–sea ﬂux. Among the two exceptions, only oneresults in a signiﬁcant outgassing; it corresponds,
however, to an unrealistically low average f-ratio
(last line of Table 4 ).
The DOAM outputs allowed for the ﬁrst
time a description of the spatial and seasonalvariability of the carbon cycle in the MediterraneanSea, and of the respective role of mixing, biologyand air–sea exchange. This analysis reveals thedominant role of air–sea CO
2exchange and
biology, which both largely determine the impor-
tant differences between the east and the westMediterranean basins. The ultra-oligotrophiceastern Mediterranean is oversaturated in CO
2
for most of the year, while the spring phyto-plankton blooms signiﬁcantly contribute to theundersaturation of the western Mediterraneansurface layers.
The DOAM approach may still be improved, for
instance by introducing an advection scheme tobetter simulate the physical and biogeochemicalﬁelds in dynamic areas, such as the Alboran Sea orthe southern Adriatic, or to extend its temporalrange of applicability. The approach using horizon-tal surface velocities as derived from satellite radaraltimeters ( Vivier et al., 2002 ) would probably be
appropriate in the context of the present satellite-
based approach.In its present form, the ‘‘array-of-1D-models’’
approach can already be used as a tool to study
the changes in the CO
2dynamics and carbon
ﬂuxes at the regional or global scales. In somesense, it can be seen as a sophisticated satellitealgorithm. The modiﬁcations suggested abovewould certainly improve the robustness of thesimulations, which could be checked throughcomparisons of their outputs with those of coupledgeneral circulation models in selected case studies.
As consistent long-term archives of both in situ data
(e.g. Boyer et al., 2005 ;Kamykowski and Zentara,
2005) and satellite data (e.g. Antoine et al., 2005 ;
Gregg et al., 2003 ) become available, the ‘‘array of
models’’ approach will also be adapted to assess thedecadal changes of the carbon cycle at the regionalor global scales.

Eﬀect of Al-containing precursors on Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3catalyst for methanol
production
Fan Zhang, Yuan Liu, Xiaoying Xu, Panpan Yang, Ping Miao, Yulong Zhang⁎, Qi Sun
National Institute of Clean-and-Low-Carbon Energy, Beijing 102211, PR China
ARTICLE INFO
Keywords:
AluminumHydrotalciteZinc malachiteCu substitutionMethanol synthesisABSTRACT
Aluminum is an essential ingredient in the ternary Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3catalyst for methanol synthesis from syngas.
This work investigated the eﬀ ect of Al-containing precursors on Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3catalysts during catalyst pre-
paration. A series of Cu 0.6Zn0.3Al0.1catalysts with various Al-containing precursors, including Cu-Zn-Al hydro-
talcite, aluminum hydroxide and Zn-Al hydrotalcite, were prepared by co-precipitation and fractional-pre-
cipitation, respectively. The catalysts were characterized with XRD, TG, XRF, N 2physisorption, N 2O
chemisorption, SEM, TEM/EDS and TPR. Results show that the Al-containing precursor has an important eﬀ ect
on the Cu substitution by Zn in malachite lattice, leading to various performances of the obtained catalysts. Thecatalyst with Al existing as aluminum hydroxide performed high Cu substitution in the co-precipitated zinc
malachite, and exhibits better catalyst performance compared to its counterparts. Aluminum hydroxide can be asuitable Al-containing precursor for preparing the Cu/Zn/Al methanol-synthesis catalyst.
1. Introduction
Coal gasi ﬁcation and its downstream synthetic chemical industries
have attracted extensive attention from researchers worldwide because
of the abundant coal reserves [ 1–3]. Methanol, a key chemical in C1
chemistry, provides a pathway to transform synthesis gas from coalgasiﬁcation into a variety of important industrial products [ 4,5]. In
addition to the enduring industrial relevance, methanol has great po-tential for chemical storage and distribution of hydrogen, and chemical
ﬁxation of CO
2[6]. As such, methanol plays an increasingly important
role in the coal industry.
Industrial methanol is produced from synthesis gas mixtures (CO/
CO2/H2) at typical reaction conditions of 230– 280 °C and 5– 10 MPa
over Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3catalysts. The Cu-based catalyst was typically
composed of Cu, Zn, and Al, with Cu/Zn used as active components,
and Al was used as a structural promoter [ 7]. Any of the constituting
components was indispensable to the ternary Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3catalyst.
Al addition has been reported to increase the BET surface area and
copper dispersion, leading to a remarkable increase in catalyst activity,
and especially the stability [ 7,8]. The presence of Al 2O3was believed to
inhibit the thermal sintering of Cu particles under on-stream conditions[9,10].
Traditional co-precipitation is frequently employed to prepare the
Cu/ZnO/Al
2O3catalyst, and it was widely studied by researchers [ 11].
With carbonates used as precipitants, the obtained catalyst precursorscomprised a phase mixture of di ﬀerent hydroxyl carbonates, such as
zinc malachite, aurichalcite, and hydrotalcite-like (HTl) compoundswith a general formula ((Cu,Zn)
1-xAlx)(OH) 2(CO 3)x/2∙mH 2O[12,13].
Zinc malachite was regarded as the precursor of active components inthe catalyst [ 13,14], while the function of HTl compounds was con-
troversial in literatures. The Cu-based HTl compounds for methanolsynthesis from CO
2have been investigated and the obtained catalysts
exhibited good stability and catalytic activity [ 15–17]. On the contrary,
Behrens et al. [ 14,18] suggested that large quantity of HTl precursor
should be avoided in the preparation of Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3methanol-
synthesis catalyst.
It was reported that the fractional precipitation was used to prepare
eﬃcient methanol-synthesis catalysts [ 19,20], by which Al3+is pre-
cipitated independently of Cu2+and Zn2+and existed mainly as alu-
minum hydroxide. Chu et al. [ 19] synthesized the catalyst by mixing a
binary matrix containing Cu2+and Zn2+with Al 2O3support slurry,
and the obtained catalyst also showed good performance. Bahmaniet al. [ 20] prepared the Cu/ZnO/Al
2O3catalyst by co-precipitating
Cu2+and Zn2+in the presence of various aluminum hydroxide sols.
The obtained catalysts were shown stronger inter-dispersion between
Cu and ZnO, and the well-dispersed Cu nanoparticles showed improved
activity. ZnAl 2O4has been investigated as a support for Cu based cat-
alysts for methanol synthesis [ 21–23]. The spinel-type oxide is an at-
tractive oxide matrix due to its high thermal stability and mechanical
resistance [ 22]. The potential ZnAl 2O4structure can be derived from

TZn-Al hydrotalcite, which could be produced from precipitating Zn2+
with Al3+through fractional precipitation.
Catalyst precursors have signi ﬁcant in ﬂuences on the structure and
performance of catalysts [ 13,24]. In this work, catalysts containing Cu-
Zn-Al hydrotalcite, aluminum hydroxide or Zn-Al hydrotalcite were
prepared and studied. The e ﬀect of Al combining modes with Cu/ZnO
structure on the Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3catalyst were studied according to the
characterization and evaluation results.
2. Experimental
2.1. Catalyst preparation
The catalyst preparation methods were illustrated in Table 1. In co-
precipitation process, the solution of metal ions was prepared by dis-
solving the mixture of Cu(NO 3)2∙3H2O, Zn(NO 3)2∙6H2O, and Al
(NO 3)3∙9H2O in demineralized water. Then the solution was dripped
into a heated balloon ﬂask containing 100 ml of deionized water under
vigorous stirring, with concurrent ﬂow of an aqueous solution of
Na2CO3used as the precipitant. Na 2CO3solution was added with con-
trolled ﬂow rate to maintain pH of the suspension between 7.0 and 8.0.
In the fractional-precipitation process, Al3+with the designed content
of Zn2+were added into the ﬂask in the initial step, and then the so-
lution with Cu2+and Zn2+mixtures was added into the same ﬂask. pH
was, as described above, controlled by the ﬂow rate of Na 2CO3solution
in both steps. All reagents used in this work were of analytical quality/
grade provided by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Beijing Co., Ltd.
The temperatures during precipitation and aging were kept at 80 °C
by using a water bath. After aging for 2 h, the precipitate was ﬁltered
and washed to remove Na+. Conductivity of the ﬁltering water was
monitored for the complete removal of Na+. Subsequently, the pre-
cipitate was dried at 110 °C for 12 h and calcined at 350 °C under air
ﬂow for 4 h (ramping at 2 °C/min). After tableting, crushing and
screening, the catalyst with sizes between 40 –60 mesh was obtained
and ready for evaluation. The Cu 2(OH) 2CO3and CuO samples were also
prepared by using the co-precipitation method at the same condition.
2.2. Catalyst characterization
X-ray di ﬀraction (XRD) analysis was performed by a Bruker D8
Advance X-ray di ﬀraction system using the Cu K line (1.5406 Å) ob-
tained at 40 kV/40 mA, with 2θ ranging from 10° to 80° [ 5]. Chemical
compositions of the catalysts were determined by a X-ray ﬂuorescence
spectroscopy (XRF), using a Rigaku ZSX Primus IIX-Ray spectrometer
which is equipped with an Rh target X-ray tube at 3 kW. Thermo-
gravimetric (TG) analysis was carried out using a Netzsch STA 449F3
Jupiter thermogravimetric di ﬀerential thermal analyzer. The catalyst
samples were heated up to 750 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in
theﬂow of synthetic air (30 ml/min). Speci ﬁc surface area of the
samples was measured using a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 equipment.Before measurement, the sample was de-gassed in the Micromeritics
system at 300 °C for 3 h prior to adsorption.
Scanning electron microscope (SEM) was carried out by a JSM-
5900LV type (Japan) series instrument with a Schottky ﬁeld emissiongun at an accelerating voltage of 20 kV. Transmission electron micro-scopy (TEM) images were taken with a JEOL 2011 Electron Microscope
operating at 200 kV. Simultaneous energy dispersive X-ray spectro-
scopy (EDS) was used to analyze the element distributions in di ﬀerent
part of samples [ 5]. The catalyst reducibility was examined by a tem-
perature-programmed reduction (TPR) using a Micromeritics Autochem
II 2920 auto adsorption apparatus. The catalyst sample (100 mg) was
degassed at 300 °C under Ar for 1 h. After cooling to 50 °C, 10 vol% H
2/
Ar with a ﬂow rate of 50 ml/min was introduced into the sample cell.
The temperature was ramped linearly to 300 °C with a heating rate of
2 °C/min, and then ramped to 800 °C at 10 °C/min. H 2consumption was
determined by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) in the test.
The dispersion of Cu ( DCu) and the exposed Cu surface area ( SCu)
were measured on a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 auto adsorptionapparatus. The speci ﬁc method was described elsewhere [ 5]. Generally,
the sample was ﬁrstly reduced in a 10% H
2/Ar mixture for 1 h at 300 °C.
The amount of H 2consumption was denoted as X. Then, the reduced
samples were cooled to 65 °C and exposed to a ﬂow of 10%N 2O/Ar
(50 ml/min). Finally, the H 2/Ar mixture was used to reduce the sample
at 300 °C again and the amount of H 2consumption was denoted as Y.

2.3. Catalyst evaluation
The catalyst evaluation was described in detail elsewhere [ 5].
Generally, the experiment was performed in a constant-pressure ﬁxed-
bed reactor, as shown in Fig. 1. A catalyst sample (100 mg, 40– 60 mesh)
was diluted with 1 g quartz sand (40 –60 mesh) and the mixture was
placed in the ﬂat-temperature zone of the reactor. The catalyst was
reduced in a gas mixture (5%H 2, 95%N 2) at 230 °C under atmospheric
pressure before reaction. Then the test was carried out at the conditions
of 230 °C, 5 MPa, and GHSV = 10,000 h−1with the feed gas composed
of 80% H 2, 13% CO, 2% CO 2and 5% N 2(Air Liquide). Liquid products
were separated through a water-cooled condenser and collected into a
vial. The remaining gas products were quantitatively analyzed with an
online gas chromatograph [ 5].
3. Results and discussions
3.1. Characterization of catalyst precursors
During the catalyst preparation, a small fraction of precursor sam-
ples were collected and characterized by XRD and TG, as shown in
Fig. 2 andFig. 3. The results of Cu 2(OH) 2CO3were also presented for
reference. According to the XRD results, both zinc malachite and Cu-Zn-Al hydrotalcite were found in sample HT. With Al
3+precipitated in the
initial step, only hydroxy carbonates (zinc malachite and aurichalcite)were observed in the XRD pattern of sample AH, which is corre-
sponding to other researchers' results [ 20]. Aluminum is supposed to
exist as ﬁnely dispersed Al
2O3, and thus cannot be detected by XRD. In
the pattern of sample ZAH, peaks at 11.758°, 23.643° and 34.728° were
attributed to Zn-Al hydrotalcite. Part of Zn2+was precipitated with
Al3+in the initial step, and then zinc malachite was produced in the
second step. Zinc malachite is derived from the malachite crystalstructure by substituting part of the Cu
2+ions with Zn2+, which led to
a shift of the d (20 1) position [ 14,20], as shown in Fig. 2 b. The shift
scales linearly with the amount of incorporated zinc into the malachiteTable 1

3.3. The reducibility of Cu/Zn/Al catalysts
The calcined catalyst samples were also analyzed by H
2-TPR mea-
surements from room temperature to 900 °C. The reduction pro ﬁles of
all samples exhibited a broad reduction peak accompanied by a small
shoulder in the temperature range 100 –200 °C, as shown in Fig. 7. Since
ZnO and Al 2O3could not be reduced before 200 °C, H 2consumption
was ascribed to CuO reduction. There are several discussions on the
analysis of CuO reduction pro ﬁles. Gao et al. [ 27] suggested that the
peaks in the pro ﬁle could be ascribed to the reduction of di ﬀerent CuO
phases: the low-temperature peak was caused by the reduction of dis-
persed CuO, whereas the peak appearing at high temperature was at-
tributed to the reduction of bulk CuO. Kühl et al. [ 31] considered that
the reduction of CuO might be accompanied by the formation of a quite
stable intermediate (Cu 2O). Another explanation was that the TPR
proﬁles might be divided into three peaks: the ﬁrst reduction peak
belonged to copper oxide of the surface layer (surface CuO) which was
in direct contact with ZnO species; the second reduction peak corre-
sponded to an intermediate layer (bulk-intermediate CuO) being in-
directly in ﬂuenced by ZnO due to several atomic layer distance,
whereas the third peak ﬁtted to reduction of core layer of copper oxide
(bulk-core CuO) [ 20]. In sample HT, a part of CuO was derived from the
decomposition of HTl compounds, which was supposed to be embeddedin an amorphous Zn eAl oxide matrix, leading to relatively higher re-
duction temperatures [ 18,31].
In this work, the TPR pro ﬁles of samples AH and ZAH were de-
convoluted into two Gaussian-type peaks, and the pro ﬁle of sample HTwas deconvoluted into three peaks. The peak positions and areas ob-tained by the deconvolution were presented in Table 5. As described
above, peak αwas assigned to the reduction of highly dispersed CuO;
peak βwas related to the reduction of bulk CuO; and peak γin sample
HT was ascribed to the HTl-derived CuO crystals. Accordingly, the ratioof dispersed CuO in the catalyst samples increased in the following
sequence: HT < ZAH < AH. The result was in good accordance with
the XRD analysis. Large amount of Cu substituted by Zn may bene ﬁt the
formation of dispersed CuO. Zinc malachite as a catalyst precursorcould result in more active catalysts than those with malachite as a
main component [ 32].

In stage I, the CO conversion of catalyst samples changed in the

As shown in Fig. 8, the CO conversion of sample AH, ZAH and HT

The catalyst sample with high Zn contents in the malachite lattice

It was reported that the aluminum ion was an important promoter
and it could be doped into the structure of zinc malachite during co-
precipitation [ 6]. When hydrotalcite-like compounds were used as the
precursor, the aluminum ion was trapped in the brucitic (MII,MIII)(OH) 2
layers which were built from the edge-sharing octahedral, hence lost
the ability for serving as a promoter [ 18]. This could explain the reason
that sample ZAH had the similar Cu substitution degree, while its cat-alytic activity was much lower compared to sample AH. In brief, alu-
minum hydroxide provided the disengaged Al
3+used for modifying the
co-produced zinc malachite, which demonstrated as an e ﬀective Al-
containing precursor for preparing the Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3methanol
synthesis catalyst by precipitation methods.
5. Conclusions
A series of Cu 0.6Zn0.3Al0.1catalysts with various precursors were
synthesized by using di ﬀerent Al addition methods. Cu substitution of
zinc malachite was examined by XRD of catalyst precursors. Various
phase compositions of the precursors caused by addition of Al-con-
taining precursors were veri ﬁed by the TG results. With aluminum
hydroxide as the Al-containing precursor, the calcined sample demon-strated relatively small CuO crystals and high speci ﬁc surface area. TPR
results revealed the variation of CuO particle sizes with various Al
3+
addition methods, which was in good agreement with the XRD results.
Catalyst evaluation showed that the isomorphous substitution in zinc
malachite had a good correlation with the catalyst activity. The catalyst
with an aluminum hydroxide as Al containing precursor exhibited
higher substitution degree and better catalytic performance. Aluminumhydroxide also provided the disengaged Al
3+for modifying the co-
produced zinc malachite. It was demonstrated in this research thataluminum hydroxide performed as an excellent Al-containing precursor
for combining Al with the active component of Cu/ZnO in the methanol
synthesis catalyst.

Abstract:   A series of CuO/ZnO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Al 2O3 contents  were prepared us ing the parallel-s lurry-mixing  
method, in  which an  aqueo us sol ution of Cu2+ and Zn2+ mixed  nitrates and a n aqueous solution of  Na2CO 3 were poured into a 
precipitation vessel containing  γ-Al2O3 slurry in a parallel-flow  manner. The  catalys t structure and  its performance  for methanol 
synthesis were in vestigated. The results indicated that Al 2O3 as a structural promoter can inhibit C uO and ZnO crystallites fro m 
enlarging during calcination.  The catalyst with a Cu/Z n/Al ratio of 4/5/1 (molar ratio) exhibits the highest catalytic activity . With an 
increase in Al co ntent, the amount  of (Cu 0.3Zn0.7)5(CO3)2(OH)6 phas e in the catalyst precursor be fore calcination decreases, whereas  
that of C u2CO 3(OH) 2 phase  incre ases; (Cu 0.3Zn0.7)5(CO 3)2(OH)6 in the precursor is beneficial to the catalytic activity  of the final 
Cu/ZnO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. 
Key Words:   methanol synthesis; CuO/Zn O/γ-Al2O3; parallel-slurry-mixing; catalyst precursors; role of Al2O3

vapors of Cu, Zn, and Al with fuel and air, which may 
efficiently  control the uniform  disp ersion o f copper, zinc, 
and alu minum compone nts at  the m olecular  level, and  a 
cataly st with l arge surface a rea, high activity , and good  
thermostability  is obtain ed. Shen et al .[3] prepared a  
ceria-supp orted  copper cataly st through coprecipitation; the  
cataly st is a ctive for methanol sy nthesis even at a  
temperature below 200 °C. Usin g the chem ical

of nickel- modified multiwall ed carbon nanotube material 
Ni/M WCNT, and Ni/M WCNT-prom oted Cu-ZnO-Al 2O3 
cataly st prepared through coprecipitation method exhibite d

Although the  conventional  precipitation  is a mature 
method to prepare the co pper-base d cat alyst, various modific ations have been made, which has attracted much 
attention. These modificati ons may be su mmarized as two  
categorie s: (1) addition of different metal ele ments su ch as 
Zr, V,  Ce, Ga, and M n[5−9]; (2) im provement of the 
precipitation pr ocess. Be sides the ty pical precipitation modes 
such a s forwar d, reverse, and parallel-flow an d parallel-drip 
coprecipitatio ns, so me novel precipitation te chnique s lik e 
high-speed  collision[10], gel-network[11], and 
urea-hy droly sis[12] coprecipita tions have been reported  
recently . Li et al .[13] found that the  insonation of the  
suspen sion du ring precipitati on and agin g step s could  
enhanc e the activity of copper-based cataly sts appreciably . 
Yu et al.[14] reported that the c opper-based cat alyst prepare d 
using du al-frequency  ultraso nic method exhibits high er 
activity than t hat obtained by s ingle-frequency ultras onic 
method. It should be point ed out that the particles o f 
Al-co mpone nt precipitate f ormed i n the  coprecipitatio n 
processe s are so fine that a n effective washing of the  
precipitate is ra ther difficult. Moreov er, many researche s on 
the copper-base d cataly st conc erned only  the effects of Cu 
and Zn com ponents on its structure and property[15−22], 
wherea s the inv estigatio n on the effects of Al co mponent w as 
rarely  reported . The study  about the effect of Al 2O3 on 
cataly st struct ure and prope rty may offer so me useful 
infor mation to improve the activity  and therm ostability  of GUO Xian-ji et al. / Journal of Fuel Ch emistry and Technology, 2007, 35(3): 329 −333 
 
copper-based catalyst. It has been reported that optimum 
Cu/Zn ratio is largely dependent on the method of preparation
[23], but it is not clear whether the optimum Al 
content is also related to the method of preparation. 
In this study, a series of Cu-based catalysts with various 
Al contents were prepared using a parallel-slurry-mixing 
technique. The relationships among the catalyst structure, 
catalytic activity, and the Al content were investigated. 
 
1  Experimental 
 
1.1  Catalyst preparation 
 
A series of copper-based catalysts, CuO/ZnO/ γ-Al 2O3, 
with a fixed Cu/Zn ratio (Cu/Zn = 4/5) and different Al 
contents were prepared using the parallel-slurry-mixing 
technique. γ-Al 2O3–water slurry was first obtained in a 
beaker, with γ-Al 2O3 ground and sieved to less than 300 
mesh. An aqueous solution containing copper nitrate and 
zinc nitrate and an aqueous solution of sodium carbonate 
were simultaneously added into the precipitating vessel 
containing the γ-Al 2O3–water slurry in parallel-flow manner 
with vigorous stirring. The final suspension was aged at 70 
°C for 2 h, then filtered and washed, and subsequently dried 
to give the catalyst precursors. After grinding, the precursors 
were calcined in an oven to form the reference catalysts (unreduced). 
 
1.2  Catalytic test  
 
Catalytic tests were carried out using a MR-GC 80 
microreactor equipped with an on-line gas chromatograph. A total of 0.5 mL of catalyst sample diluted with quartz sand 
(both with a particle size of 0.45 −0.90 mm) at a volume ratio 
of 1:1 was placed in a stainless-steel tubular reactor, and then 
reduced in situ by passing the feed gas at a space velocity of 
8000 h
−1. 
The reaction of methanol synthesis was operated under 
483− 553 K, 4 MPa, H 2/CO/CO 2 = (66−67)/(31−32)/(1−2), 
and an inlet space velocity of 10000 h−1. The product stream 
was analyzed with an on-line 103-type gas chromatograph instrument equipped with a GDX-103 column and a TCD 
detector. 
 
1.3  Thermal analysis of catalyst precursors  
 
Thermal analysis of the catalyst precursors (DTA) was 
performed with a CDR-1 thermal analyzer by heating a sample (20 mg) at ramp of 20 K ⋅min
−1 from 298 to 773 K in 
nitrogen flow (25 mL ⋅min−1). Before the DTA measurement 
was made, all samples were thoroughly dried at 353 K. 
 1.4  XRD patterns  
 
Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD ) patterns were recorded 
on a Rigaku D/MAX-3B diffractometer with Ni-filtered 
Cu-Kα radiation at a scanning rate of 5º/min. Before the 
measurement was made, the samples were ground and sieved 
to less than 300 meshes. 
 
1.5  IR spectra 
 
Infrared (IR) spectra were me asured in the range of 
400–1000 cm−1 with a Perkin-Elmer 1710 FT-IR 
spectrometer using a KBr pellet containing the corresponding 
sample. 
 
2  Results and discussion 
 
2.1  Catalytic activity and Al content 
 
Fig. 1 shows the change in methanol yield and CO 
conversion over the copper-based catalyst prepared using the 
parallel-slurry-mixing technique with temperature. For 
comparison, the one-step parallel flow coprecipitation method
[24] was also employed to prepare a copper-based 
catalyst with a Cu/Zn/Al ratio of 4/5/1. 
These two catalysts with the same composition exhibit no 
obvious difference in the catalytic activity, although the 
catalyst prepared using the parallel-slurry-mixing technique 
exhibits a relatively broad active-temperature range and gives a higher catalytic activity at high temperature (553 K). 
However, the parallel-slurry-mixing technique is more 
advantageous, because washing of the precipitate in the parallel-slurry-mixing precipitation technique, where the Al 
component is added in the form of γ-Al
2O3 slurry, is much 
easier than that in the one-step parallel flow coprecipitations 
technique, as mentioned previously. 
It was pointed out that the promoting effect of Al 2O3 on 
the catalytic activity is dependent on its improvement of  the 
catalyst structure[18]. Catalytic activities of copper-based 
catalyst with various Al contents are shown in Table 1. The 
catalyst with a Cu/Zn/Al ratio of 4/5/1 exhibits the highest 
activity, which is much higher than that of the binary 
Cu/ZnO catalyst with the same Cu/Zn ratio. The BET surface 
area of the former is 45 m2/g and that of the latter is only 27 
m2/g. This indicates that Al 2O3 is a typical structural 
promoter. The optimum Al content of the ternary copper-based catalyst is found to be approximately 10.0% 
(by mol), which is similar to the value of 9.5% obtained by 
Zhao et al.
[21] using a pH-following-the-track technique. 
Very high Al content leads to a decline in the catalytic 
activity. This suggests that the optimum Al content is not 
dependent on the method of preparation. GUO Xian-ji et al. / Journal of Fuel Chemistry a nd Technolog y, 2007, 35( 3): 329−333

3  Conclusions 
 
(1) A series of CuO/ZnO/ γ-Al 2O3 catalysts with high activity 
for methanol synthesis were prepared using parallel-slurry-mixing method. Such a preparation process, 
especially the step of precipitate washing, is much easer than the coprecipitation process. 
(2) The optimum Al content in the ternary copper-based catalyst is approximately 10.0% (by mol), and it is not dependent on the method of preparation. 
(3) Al component acts as a structural promoter and restrains the active component grains from enlarging during the calcination of catalyst precursors. 
(4) The formation of catalyst precursor phase depends on Al content. With a low Al content, (Cu
0.3Zn0.7)5(CO 3)2(OH) 6 is 
the main phase in the precursors; with an increase in Al 
content, (Cu 0.3Zn0.7)5(CO 3)2(OH) 6 phase decreases and 
Cu2CO 3(OH) 2 phase increases. The phase 
(Cu 0.3Zn0.7)5(CO 3)2(OH) 6 is beneficial to the catalytic activity 
of the final Cu/ZnO/ γ-Al 2O3 catalyst.

Carbon dioxide (CO 2) is one of greenhouse gases, which can cause global warming.
One of studies to mitigate CO 2emissions to the atmosphere is to convert CO 2to
valuable products (i.e., methanol). To make methanol produ ction via CO 2hydrogenation
a competitive process, the optimal operating conditions wi th minimum production
cost need to be considered. This paper studied an applicatio n of response surface
methodology (RSM) in optimization of methanol production v ia CO2hydrogenation.
The objective of this optimization was to minimize the metha nol production cost per
tons produced methanol. The sensitivity analysis was perfo rmed to determine the
parameters that show signiﬁcant impacts on the methanol pro duction cost. Response
surface methodology coupled with non-linear programming s olver were used as the
optimization tool. The results showed RSM was successfully applied to the methanol
productionviaCO 2hydrogenationprocess.Theobtainedminimummethanolprod uction
cost was $565.54 per ton produced methanol with the optimal o perating conditions as
follows. Inlet pressure to the ﬁrst reactor: 57.8 bar, Inlet temperature to the ﬁrst reactor:
183.6◦C,Inletpressuretothesecondreactor:102.6bar,Outlette mperatureoftheliquid
stream cooler after the second reactor: 63.5◦C, Inlet temperature to the ﬁrst distillation
column: 51.8◦C.
Keywords: methanol production, CO 2hydrogenation, response surface methodology, simulation bas ed
optimization, sensitivity analysis
INTRODUCTION
Most of energy in the world is currently from combustion of carb onaceous fuels, which are coal,
oil, and natural gas. CO 2emission from this combustion is considered as the second con tribution
tothegreenhouseeﬀect(9–26%),afterthewatervaporandclouds (36–72%).Therecentattempts
predictthatCO 2willshowstrongergreenhouseeﬀectwhenitsamountintheatmo sphereisdouble
(Jaworowski et al., 1992 ). The net CO 2emissions could increase at around 5.4% over the next few
decades(Radhi,2009 ).Duetothisconcern,manyapplicationsandresearchesonCO 2conversion
andutilizationhavebeenstudiedtocontrolamountofCO 2releasingtotheatmosphere.CO 2can
eitherbeuseddirectlyorasfeedstocktoproduceusefulchem icalsandmaterials.Forthedirectuse,
CO2isutilizedinmanydiﬀerentapplicationssuchasfoodpreservat ion,beveragecarbonation,ﬁre
extinguisher,supercriticalextraction,dryice,etc( Songetal.,2002 ).ForconversionofCO 2toother
products,ureasynthesisisthelargestproductionwhilethem ethanolsynthesisisthesecondlargest
productioninthisarea( Naims,2016 ).Borisut and Nuchitprasittichai Optimization of Methanol Production
Methanol is commonly used as both solvent and reactant
in chemical industry. Uses of methanol is found in many
household products, including paints, varnishes, cleaning
products ( Dasgupta and Klein, 2014 ). Moreover, methanol can
use as a motor fuel or gasoline blending component ( Ingamells
andLindquist,1975 ).Themethanol—fueledvehiclesuseablend
of85percentmethanolwith15percentunleadedgasoline(M85)
(Ingamells and Lindquist, 1975; EPA, 2002; Bukhtiyarova et a l.,
2017).Fromlaboratoryandroadtestsindicatethataddingof10%
methanolcanraiseoctane2–3numbers.Intheresearchof Gabele
(1990),theresultsshowedthatincreaseofmethanolcontentdoes
notaﬀecttheemissionrateofexhaustgas.
In the conventional methanol production, methanol
is produced from petroleum product (synthesis gas) via
hydrogenation of CO and CO 2, and reversed water—gas
shift reaction ( María et al., 2013 ). The commercial methanol
productions from synthesis gas use CuO/ZnO/Al 2O3as catalyst
(Sayah et al., 2010; Jadhav et al., 2014 ). The commercial
CuO/ZnO/Al 2O3coupled with a zeolite membrane reactor can
provide higher CO 2conversion, methanol yield, and selectivity
compared with a traditional reactor ( Gallucci et al., 2004 ).
Copper based catalyst is mostly used for CO 2hydrogenation to
methanol due to its cheap and higher catalyst activity ( Ali et al.,
2015). Saito and Murata studied of Al 2O3supported Cu-based
catalyst with Co-precipitation technique. The catalyst show s
high activity and the stability was improved by adding colloi dal
silica(SaitoandMurata,2004 ).
Severaldevelopmentsofcatalystsusedincatalyticconvers ion
toimprovetheperformanceofcatalystwerestudied.MgandMn
was promoted on CuZnZr catalyst. Adding of MgO and MnO
lead to increase in catalytic activity of the catalyst ( Sloczy´nski
et al., 2003 ). Doping of Mn to Cu/Zn/Zr catalyst can increase
the methanol production rate. The zirconium indicates the
advantageous inﬂuence on the catalyst activity ( Lachowska and
Skrzypek,2004 ).ThePd/ZnOcatalystsovermulti-walledcarbon
nanotubes was found to have the turnover frequency reached
0.015persecond( Liangetal.,2009 ).
Recently, the production of methanol from direct CO 2
hydrogenation is of interest ( Samimi et al., 2017; Marlin et al.,
2018). The process has potential to mitigate the CO 2emission
to the atmosphere. The methanol production from direct CO 2
(using pure sources of CO 2and H2) has several advantages
over the conventional process—it results in signiﬁcantly le ss
byproducts, and requires less energy in product puriﬁcation
(Marlinetal.,2018 ).However,themethanolproductioncostvia
direct CO 2hydrogenation is 2–2.5 times higher than the cost
of conventional process ( Atsonics et al., 2015 ). The process of
methanol production via CO 2hydrogenation consumes more
utilities than the conventional methanol production ( Machado
etal.,2014 ).
There are some studies on simulation—based optimization
of methanol synthesis to increase the methanol production
rate (Hoseiny et al., 2016; Leonzio, 2017 ). For methanol
productionfromsynthesisgas,theeﬀectsofchangesinoperati ng
conditions on the production rate were studied to maximize
the production rate. The studied operating parameters were
feed ﬂow rate, pressure and temperature of feed, and thecoolingwatertemperature.Theresultsshowedthatthemetha nol
production rate can be increased by 7% with higher feed
pressure and lower feed temperature ( Hoseiny et al., 2016 ).
For methanol synthesis via direct CO 2hydrogenation, Grazia
Leonzio developed mathematical model of the reactor used
in methanol production. The impacts of reaction temperature,
reaction pressure, H 2/CO2ratio, and the recycle factor on
methanol production rate and reactor volume were studied
(Leonzio,2017 ).
However, optimization of methanol production via CO 2
hydrogenation, which considers all possible operating
parameters, for the minimum production cost has not been
studied. This paper studied an application of response surface
methodology (RSM) in optimization of methanol production
via CO 2hydrogenation process. To be able to apply the RSM
in optimization, the response surface has to be in the form
of the second order model. The sensitivity analysis was used
to determine the signiﬁcant operating parameters. The RSM
coupled with non-linear solver was employed to obtain the
local optimal operating conditions and the minimum methanol
productioncost.

Simulation—Optimization
In this section, RSM ( Nuchitprasittichai and Cremaschi, 2011 )
coupled with non-linear solver were employed to optimize
the methanol production via CO 2hydrogenation process. The
objective is to minimize the methanol production cost per
tons produced methanol ($/tons produced methanol). Response
surface methodology is a statistical tool used to represent
the relationship between independent variables and dependen t
variable(s). In this work, RSM was employed to represent the
relationship between signiﬁcant operating parameters and th e
methanol production cost per tons produced methanol. The
signiﬁcant operating parameters (decision variables) are th e
signiﬁcant parameters obtained from sensitivity analysis (i n
sectionSensitivityanalysis)whicharex 1:inletpressuretothe1st
reactor, x 2: inlet temperature to the 1st reactor, x 3: inlet pressure
to the 2nd reactor, x 4: outlet temperature of the liquid stream
cooler after the 2nd reactor, x 5: inlet temperature to the 1st
distillationcolumn.
Figure4 represents simulation—optimization algorithm. In
the algorithm, the range of each decision variables was ﬁrstdetermined. In this work, the ranges of decision variables
were obtained from literature ( Shen et al., 2000; Witoon
et al., 2015 ). Factorial design with two levels (2kFactorial
design, section 2kFactorial design) and a center point were
used as a data set of the decision variables. Then, process
simulation, coupled with cost analysis, was run corresponding
to operating conditions in the data set to obtained methanol
production costs. The data of operating conditions and the
corresponding methanol production costs were combined and
ﬁt the ﬁrst order model by regression analysis (using Design
Expert 11 software). If the data ﬁt the ﬁrst order model
(R—squared >0.7), it means that the region of operating
conditions and methanol production costs is in linear region.
The steepest descent (section Steepest descent) was performed
to move operating conditions to the region of lower methanol
production cost. On the other hand, if the data do not ﬁt
the ﬁrst order model, it means that the data are in non-
linear region. The Box—Behnken Design [BBD, section Box—
Behnken design (BBD)] was performed to collect more data
in non-linear region. All data were then combined to ﬁt the
second order (non-linear) model. The non-linear model was
then used as the objective function in optimization problem.

The optimization formulation was solved in the Intel
Pentium 4 processor, core i3. The local optimal solutions
were obtained in 2s. The obtained minimum production
cost ($ per tons produced methanol) is an oﬀset between
the methanol production cost and the amount of produced
methanol. The methanol production cost includes energy
consumption, utilities, and capital cost costs. For the optima l
solution, the amount of produced methanol increased so that
the minimum production cost per tons of produced methanol
was obtained. The optimal methanol production rate is 964
kmoles per hours, which produced from 1,000 kmoles per
hour of feed carbon dioxide and 3,000 kmoles per hour of
feedhydrogen.CONCLUSION
In the optimization of methanol production via CO 2
hydrogenation, the sensitivity analysis coupled with RSM
was successfully represent the relationship between methano l
production operating conditions and the methanol production
costpertonsproducedmethanol($pertonproducedmethanol).
The non-linear solver was applied to optimize the non-linear
relationship model for the minimum methanol production cost.
Two reactors were employed in the process. In the optimal
region of study, the inlet pressure and temperature to the ﬁrst
reactor show signiﬁcant impacts on the methanol production
cost. The optimal operating conditions of inlet pressure to the
ﬁrst reactor is 57.8 bar, inlet temperature to the ﬁrst reacto r
is 183.6◦C, and the other three insigniﬁcant parameters were
set at their lower bounds. The obtained minimum methanol
productioncostis$565.54pertonproducedmethanol.

A Detailed Process and Techno-Economic Analysis of Methanol
Synthesis from H 2and CO 2with Intermediate Condensation Steps
Bruno Lacerda de Oliveira Campos *, Kelechi John, Philipp Beeskow, Karla Herrera Delgado *
 , Stephan Pitter
 ,
Nicolaus Dahmen and Jörg Sauer
Institute of Catalysis Research and Technology (IKFT), Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT),
Hermann-von Helmholtz-Platz 1, D-76344 Eggenstein-Leopoldshafen, Germany
*Correspondence: bruno.campos@kit.edu (B.L.d.O.C.); karla.herrera@kit.edu (K.H.D.)
Abstract: In order to increase the typically low equilibrium CO 2conversion to methanol using
commercially proven technology, the addition of two intermediate condensation units between
reaction steps is evaluated in this work. Detailed process simulations with heat integration and
techno-economic analyses of methanol synthesis from green H 2and captured CO 2are presented here,
comparing the proposed process with condensation steps with the conventional approach. In the new
process, a CO 2single-pass conversion of 53.9% was achieved, which is signiﬁcantly higher than the
conversion of the conventional process (28.5%) and its equilibrium conversion (30.4%). Consequently,
the total recycle stream ﬂow was halved, which reduced reactant losses in the purge stream and the
compression work of the recycle streams, lowering operating costs by 4.8% (61.2 M €·a−1). In spite of
the additional number of heat exchangers and ﬂash drums related to the intermediate condensation
units, the ﬁxed investment costs of the improved process decreased by 22.7% (94.5 M €). This was a
consequence of the increased reaction rates and lower recycle ﬂows, reducing the required size of the
main equipment. Therefore, intermediate condensation steps are beneﬁcial for methanol synthesis
from H 2/CO 2, signiﬁcantly boosting CO 2single-pass conversion, which consequently reduces both
the investment and operating costs.
Keywords: methanol synthesis; CO 2utilization; power-to-X; intermediate condensation steps;
product removal; techno-economic analysis; heat integration; plant simulation
1. Introduction
Sustainable solutions are required to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions of the
transportation and industrial sectors, shrinking the dependency on fossil fuels. With the
continuously increasing installed capacity of wind and solar power plants [ 1], adequate
energy storage solutions have to be implemented in order to deal with their ﬂuctuating
nature. Therefore, the conversion of electricity into valuable chemicals and fuels, a concept
often called power-to-fuels or power-to-X, can make an important contribution to the
future energy system [ 2]. In this context, key process steps are hydrogen generation via
electrolysis (primary conversion) [ 3,4] and methanol synthesis (secondary conversion) [ 5].
Methanol can be used as a fuel substitute or additive, either in fuel cells or via
combustion [2] , as a feedstock in the production of base chemicals (e.g., formaldehyde)
and liquid fuels (e.g., gasoline, oxymethylene ethers, jetfuel) [ 6–8], and also as a solvent.
Methanol fuel has recently attracted signiﬁcant interest, especially in China, where the
consumption of methanol for thermal applications (e.g., boilers, kilns, cooking stoves) and
in the transportation section amounted to 5.7 Mton ·a−1(year 2019) [9].
The current global capacity of methanol production is 164 Mton ·a−1(year 2021), with
an annual increase of 10% projected for the next decade [ 10]. Traditionally, methanol
synthesis is fed by fossil-based syngas, which comes either from steam reforming of natural
gas or from coal gasiﬁcation [ 11]. However, sustainable syngas production is gaining
